Official Helium Community
‚∏∫ HIP-Archive ‚∏∫ / hip-45-lora-frequency-selection
Tracking/discussion issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/311
jamiedubs 11/13/2021 9:42 AM
https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/311 - Author(s): @lthiery, @ivandigiusto - Start Date: 2021-10-25 - Category: Technical - Original HIP PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/298 - Tracking Issue: this - Status: In Discussion # Problem Statement [problem_statement]: #ProblemStatement There are over a dozen of officially recognized LoRaWAN channel plans cited in the LoRaWAN Regional Specification. In each region, the Helium Network must select one and only one frequency plan (based on current design constraints). In cases where only one channel plan is possible (eg: Anguilla) or where only one has regulatory type approval (eg: American Samoa), the selection for the Helium Network may default to that one. This HIP proposes methodology for the selection of a channel plan for each region. # Rendered View https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/master/0045-lorawan-frequency-plan-selection.md
HIP 45: LoRaWAN Frequency Plan Selection · Issue #311 · helium/HIP

Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.

theskywatcher 12/03/2021 12:36 PM
How hard is this to implement
theskywatcher
How hard is this to implement
louis 12/08/2021 1:25 PM
Most of this HIP is procedure/governance. After a successful new selection, updating the chain_var that describes which region is which frequency plan is relatively trivial. Basically, there's no real blockchain development that goes into this.
1

zl3ag 12/18/2021 4:29 AM
Those are the limits for unwanted emissions (birdies etc) coming from the transmitter, not the actual wanted signal?
ScuL 12/18/2021 4:35 AM
I believe currently hotspots are capped to 27dBm so it would give us slightly more
lalalachi 12/19/2021 2:23 AM
I notice that POC 11 applies EIRP limit to 16dBm (40mW) for all as923 band countries which affects the reward dramatically in the past few days. In fact, most of the countries who use AS923 band can allow the TX up to 27dBm. In the case of Taiwan NCC official documentation, the TX power limits should be set to 30dBm/ 1W indoor and 27dBm/0.5W outdoor. However, POC 11 applies 16dBm EIRP limitation to all AS923 band countries which is unfair. This really discourage most of Helium Hotspot owners in AS923 band countries. Please consider applying correct EIRP limitations for each country. (edited)
4
lalalachi
I notice that POC 11 applies EIRP limit to 16dBm (40mW) for all as923 band countries which affects the reward dramatically in the past few days. In fact, most of the countries who use AS923 band can allow the TX up to 27dBm. In the case of Taiwan NCC official documentation, the TX power limits should be set to 30dBm/ 1W indoor and 27dBm/0.5W outdoor. However, POC 11 applies 16dBm EIRP limitation to all AS923 band countries which is unfair. This really discourage most of Helium Hotspot owners in AS923 band countries. Please consider applying correct EIRP limitations for each country. (edited)

robotsang 02/12/2022 5:50 PM
Hi guys, I am from Malaysia. We have the same problem here. I posted my feedback here: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/311 Basically I am super happy to know this HIP has been approved. But just to make sure it helps Helium network in Malaysia. Allow me to explain again here.
HIP 45: LoRaWAN Frequency Plan Selection · Issue #311 · helium/HIP
Author(s): @lthiery, @ivandigiusto Start Date: 2021-10-25 Category: Technical Original HIP PR: #298 Tracking Issue: this Status: Approved Problem Statement There are over a dozen of officially reco...
robotsang 02/13/2022 12:50 AM
Hi guys, I am from Malaysia. We have the same problem here. The allowed frequency by Malaysia authority (MCMC) is actually 919-923MHz with an EIRP of 500mW (max), and 923-924MHz with an EIRP of 500mW (max) and some extra conditions. So legally, LoRa or LongFi should not transmit outside of 919 - 924MHz and best is to stay within 919-923MHz only. The official document is here: https://www.mcmc.gov.my/skmmgovmy/media/General/pdf/Class-Assignment-No-1-of-2021_.pdf, page 10 of 74. However, referring to LoRa Alliance document: https://lora-alliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/RP002-1.0.3-FINAL-1.pdf, page 15 of 94, there are 3 frequency bands listed for Malaysia, 433-435MHz(EU433), 916-919MHz(AS923-1), 919-924MHz (AS923-1). But the helium hotspots in Malaysia are transmitting at the frequencies of 923.2, 923.4, 923.6, 923.8, 924.0, 924.2, 924.4 and 924.6MHz. These are AS923-1 in Helium network, but any freq above 924MHz are out of the freq range allowed by Malaysia authority. Even freq >923MHz have special condition of < 1% duty cycle, or freq hopping or LBT. In short preferable frequency band should be within 919-923MHz, which I think should be AS923-2 = 921.4, 921.6, 921.8, 922.0, 922.2, 922.4, 922.6 and 922.8 MHz. These freq band are within the allowed operating freq in Malaysia. At the time I post this, there are already 526 helium hotspots online according to https://www.sitebot.com/helium/locations/. All these hotpots are transmitting outside of allowed freq since powered up. And of course, any IoT developer that wanted to utilize Helium network is transmitting outside of the allowed freq too. Which, unfortunately are all illegal. I really hope to get the attention from the Helium community as more hotspots and IoT devices will get online. The more this is delayed, the more difficult it gets as IoT devices will need to be reprogrammed in order to change the frequency band.
Helium Hotspots By Country
robotsang 02/13/2022 2:16 PM
How can we know if the proposed frequency band changes for certain country is approved and will be implemented? As this will also affect type approval and certification of hotspot. Can anyone enlighten me?
HeliumDownUnder 02/17/2022 4:12 PM
Hey team, I am sorry as it appears I am late to the party on this matter, with all of the other very significant HIP's being discussed and actioned lately this one slipped off the radar. Can I get clarification on where we stand in relation to the community vote to accept the recomendations of the committee? While I have an opinion on changing something that does not seem to be broken, I am far from an expert but speaking for a large % of our AU915 community we want to be presented with the pros and cons of changing vs staying. So that we have time to have our our community Zoom call can you provide the dealine on this issue? As we are on alternate time zones to the US and Europe it is always difficult to truly be directly involved on the Helium discussions but this does not mean that we are not interested in being there. @louis @jamiedubs

louis 02/17/2022 4:25 PM
This HIP does not dictate any change for AU+NZ. It only establishes a process for changes in frequency plan. There's been a lot covered in #foundation concerning the matter today, so please review and let me know if everything sounds above board for you.
16:29
And if the AU+NZ change leads to a townhall, I assure you it will be at a time that makes the most sense for your timezone
2

HeliumDownUnder 02/17/2022 4:31 PM

I am still not totally comfortable that I understand the deadline for further discussion and an ultimate vote on the matter. While I personally don't see change as out of the question I feel that my opinion would be similar to most Aust and NZ folk, we just want to understand. Currently I have seen a few bit of information that represent the commercial side of the discussion, is there any plan that you are aware of to release the true commercial benifets of a change away from AU915? There is a high probability of hosting a AU915 community call to address concerns and voice opinions, do you know if anyone from the committee would be interested to attend this call?

scott 02/28/2022 6:57 PM
Regarding the upcoming regional community call being scheduled. Here are the meeting notes from the LoRaWAN Working Group meeting in December regarding the AU915/AS923-1 frequency plan selection: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d9W4z9Krs88zsnUkXF3OnexJ3zE4Ei9Gv2ERFfaf0B0/edit?usp=sharing My apologies that this is coming in late and a couple improvement notes: 1. DeWi will have forthcoming details about the creation and operating rules for committees and working groups in general. This has been an ad-hoc effort to date. 2. DeWi will also host a directory for all committee and working groups (including group contacts, meeting notes, and voting records)
Helium LoRaWAN Working Group 10 Dec 2021 Meeting Summary
Helium LoRaWAN Working Group 10 Dec 2021 Meeting Summary Full video Introductions (0:30 - 2:30) Introductions from Michael Vierling (Helium, Inc), Joey H (DeWi), Christina Ramsey (DeWi) HIP45/46 and Voting (2:30 - 5:45) With HIP45 (and HIP46) likely to be accepted, during this third DeWi LoR...
robotsang 03/01/2022 5:00 AM
I notice Malaysia frequency plan is being highlighted in the meeting notes. Thanks. However, not to forget the maximum EIRP too. As far as I understand, currently any region that being assigned AS923-1, the EIRP will be adjusted to 16dBm, but for Malaysia, we are allowed to transmit at max EIRP of 27dBm, that is few times less that what we should be able to transmit at. It affect our PoC and the rewards.
Zardie 03/02/2022 3:49 PM
I haven't had a complete think/research about it but I think there are a few questions now that HIP 45 has started to be be used. I think the biggest problem is that its not explicit enough. My thoughts: 1. Who is the DeWi LoRa Technical Committee (is there a constitution or other doc that describes them?) 2. which "local" Discord channels and other "standard" channels. 3. What constitutes a "formal" dissention - is just a comment on the PR enough ? 4. During the "live" public forum why isn't both sides required to present their positions (and be given a right to reply as well as field questions). This should then be incorporated into a more complete summary of positions (open question: how to remove author bias?) before being put to chain vote. 5. "frequency plan per region and/or country" - what does this mean exactly? is it a single row in Table 1 of RP002-1.0.3 LoRaWAN® Regional Parameters?

Jayce 03/04/2022 8:58 AM
@louis http://okosvaros.lechnerkozpont.hu/en/node/1052 shows that the smart cities choice in perth is locked to AU915 also that other towns such as gold coast and Sydney are about to follow suit using the TTN profile of which Helium and its miners could slot into to provide more data gateways if the 915 was left where it is,
City of Perth Free Public LoRa Network | Smart City
As part of the City of Perth‚Äôs Smart Cities engagement programme, the city is providing a free public outdoor wireless Lo Range (LoRa) Network service for its citizen scientists, residents, community groups and businesses, to promote learning and innovation with smart devices connected to a network, collectively known as the ‚ÄúInternet of Things‚Äù...

Jayce 03/04/2022 9:14 AM

09:18
Anyways have a good weekend felt you should know publicly the lora alliance wanted 915 for smart cities and now is supposed to want a freq change this finding from our team leads more questions then answers being honest but shows lora alliance supported 915 roll out in the first place. @louis have a wonderful brilliant rest of your day
gazmcghee 03/04/2022 9:15 PM
This is not a difficult choice. The "do nothing" choice is technically superior and unanimously is what the community wants, from non-tech crypto miners through to IoT professionals with commercial deals underway. Helium was always intended to be disruptive, just like Napster. The difficulty is for the incumbents to deal with being disrupted and to still retain a viable business model. I believe this is the source of the dispute, but they don't want to say it or be identified. They are in a much better position than the taxi companies or Blockbuster video when they got disrupted. The IoT network companies can still maintain their existing customers agreements uninterrupted. And now they can do corporate deals where customers get their own carrier grade AU915 (Helium or not) hardware coverage and an SLA in specified areas, plus Helium roaming more broadly without even mentioning Helium or customers entering the Helium console. This is a win-win-win-win for all 4 parties - customers, corporates, Helium Inc and the Helium community. And AU915 is best suited to handle the load which does have limits as studies have shown. It can't be fun or cheap obtaining radio sites over broad areas and maintaining gateways. Helium has destroyed that approach for far less cost. Corporates can now focus more on sales, quality and application development. However if Helium was to change to AS923, I would not be surprised to see the corporates launching premium 64 channel services on AU915 claiming it was superior to Helium. Their opposition could be because they want AU915 for themselves, not because it is inferior. Both the Lora Alliance and the Helium LoRaWAN committee are likely far more representative of overseas corporate interests than Australian community interests. But "The People's Network" has 10X the gateways & HIP45 so it should not be long before this problem goes away. In fact, why can't it be settled this coming week? Was there any ambiguity in the community response? (edited)
2
3
Gh0st 03/04/2022 10:15 PM

This is not a difficult choice. I believe this is the source of the dispute, but they don't want to say it or be identified. They are in a much better position than the taxi companies or Blockbuster video when they got disrupted. gazmcghee

pritamghanghas 03/04/2022 11:49 PM
how do you figure light hotspot will be half the price. The BOM cost for manufacturer will go down by atmost $50. That can make a max difference in sale price of $100
pritamghanghas
how do you figure light hotspot will be half the price. The BOM cost for manufacturer will go down by atmost $50. That can make a max difference in sale price of $100
gazmcghee 03/05/2022 1:00 AM
That's an interesting point. Helium has said they will sell from $99, but it's not their decision. TTN has a $99 gateway, and the difference will be minimal. This reveals the profit that scaled up manufacturers are/will be making because they know customers will be making a profit overall. The price has little to do with the manufacturing cost.
gazmcghee 03/05/2022 1:29 AM
@Gh0st @pritamghanghas this channel is for a specific issue.
Jayce 03/08/2022 2:29 PM
@louis My PA has spoken with Perth and the information they provided is the network was selected for both ease of access and price point into accessible network coverage for IOT units. I also asked if the lora alliance pushed for AU923 would Perth consider changing to engage with this lora change and the answer was NO to many IOT units working on AU915 to consider the Perth and Western Australian Government to change its mind it would cost to much. especially because the Western Australian Government has undertaken 15 Pilot projects as found at the link provided below which will allow Helium Hotspot owners on the AU915 to provide coverage for some of the data transfer including the stock movement data as the stock moves around the state. Hope this helps we could do a further freedom of information act for the full process if we needed further information about how many sensors are running AU915 and alike but we feel that the information provided is enough for us to give you an overview on their response to our basic information search https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/IoTupdate?fbclid=IwAR2m048n6P6McHHmRyhtiyz9j8l1wQniKfi8i4nymyoA1-HdLFyol7wBhFs
WA Internet of Things (IoT) Decision Ag Grants Program 2020 project...
Fifteen Internet of Things (IoT) Program projects were conducted across the state in 2020. These projects were undertaken by 13 grower groups and agricultural colleges awarded funding under the WA DecisionAg IoT Grants Program, which was run by the department‚Äôs eConnected Grainbelt Project.
Jayce
@louis My PA has spoken with Perth and the information they provided is the network was selected for both ease of access and price point into accessible network coverage for IOT units. I also asked if the lora alliance pushed for AU923 would Perth consider changing to engage with this lora change and the answer was NO to many IOT units working on AU915 to consider the Perth and Western Australian Government to change its mind it would cost to much. especially because the Western Australian Government has undertaken 15 Pilot projects as found at the link provided below which will allow Helium Hotspot owners on the AU915 to provide coverage for some of the data transfer including the stock movement data as the stock moves around the state. Hope this helps we could do a further freedom of information act for the full process if we needed further information about how many sensors are running AU915 and alike but we feel that the information provided is enough for us to give you an overview on their response to our basic information search https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/IoTupdate?fbclid=IwAR2m048n6P6McHHmRyhtiyz9j8l1wQniKfi8i4nymyoA1-HdLFyol7wBhFs

Jayce 03/08/2022 3:12 PM
No sorry Louis, you should know how Australia works, a tender is called to deliver services but prior to that tender the Government undertakes due diligence with different "INTERESTED PARTIES" or consulting companies, management teams and also the experts and makes a choice based upon the information provided. this means in hindsight that at some point someone from the lora alliance provided information around AU915 and the government chose that information to run with. it is not a "STRETCH" what is a stretch is a decision being made without all of the facts being looked at. and if we are to consider that people are already transmitting data via Helium network on AU915 to different initiatives including bush fire mitigation and as provided the smart mines with federal government backing and support a letter of support naming the helium network can be provided at any time. Personally it feels to me as though the decision has already been made when every part of evidence is dismissed in such a candied manner. No Australian wants the change, we have businesses outside the Lora alliance aka the company whom wants the change to benefit itself,whom wants to use the network available in this case the Helium Network, yet every time something is pushed forward which shows the ability of the helium network to grow and flourish you will reject it and continue to push this AU923 selection which as your Keenly aware of no one wants for Helium in Australia. (edited)

louis 03/08/2022 3:24 PM
this means in hindsight that at some point someone from the lora alliance provided information around AU915 and the government chose that information to run with
Sorry, even with additional context, this inference is absolutely not clear. The rest of your arguments are patently unfair. Nobody is dismissing arguments against the recommendation. The entire HIP45 process was developed to put final say on the hotspot operators, allowing over four weeks for arguments to be made before a final community call and a vote of hotspot operator. If that doesn't give you enough voice, there was a roughly 5 month window to discuss that process but there was zero opposition to the process. Now that the process is underway, I continuously hear baseless claims that the people against the change aren't given a voice. I don't have a strong opinion of AS923 over AU915 and I certainly don't have a vote in the matter as a DeWi LoRaWAN member nor as an Australian or NZ hotspot operator. That being said, I certainly don't find any of this foot stomping persuasive. I'd generally recommend that people against this change adopt the tact of tonysmith55 who has developed strong technical and business arguments against the change without the baseless allegations. (edited)
louis
this means in hindsight that at some point someone from the lora alliance provided information around AU915 and the government chose that information to run with
Sorry, even with additional context, this inference is absolutely not clear. The rest of your arguments are patently unfair. Nobody is dismissing arguments against the recommendation. The entire HIP45 process was developed to put final say on the hotspot operators, allowing over four weeks for arguments to be made before a final community call and a vote of hotspot operator. If that doesn't give you enough voice, there was a roughly 5 month window to discuss that process but there was zero opposition to the process. Now that the process is underway, I continuously hear baseless claims that the people against the change aren't given a voice. I don't have a strong opinion of AS923 over AU915 and I certainly don't have a vote in the matter as a DeWi LoRaWAN member nor as an Australian or NZ hotspot operator. That being said, I certainly don't find any of this foot stomping persuasive. I'd generally recommend that people against this change adopt the tact of tonysmith55 who has developed strong technical and business arguments against the change without the baseless allegations. louis 03/08/2022 3:51 PM

louis
this means in hindsight that at some point someone from the lora alliance provided information around AU915 and the government chose that information to run with
Sorry, even with additional context, this inference is absolutely not clear. The rest of your arguments are patently unfair. Nobody is dismissing arguments against the recommendation. The entire HIP45 process was developed to put final say on the hotspot operators, allowing over four weeks for arguments to be made before a final community call and a vote of hotspot operator. If that doesn't give you enough voice, there was a roughly 5 month window to discuss that process but there was zero opposition to the process. Now that the process is underway, I continuously hear baseless claims that the people against the change aren't given a voice. I don't have a strong opinion of AS923 over AU915 and I certainly don't have a vote in the matter as a DeWi LoRaWAN member nor as an Australian or NZ hotspot operator. That being said, I certainly don't find any of this foot stomping persuasive. I'd generally recommend that people against this change adopt the tact of tonysmith55 who has developed strong technical and business arguments against the change without the baseless allegations. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/08/2022 3:51 PM
but there was zero opposition to the process.
Odd... When this was first being discussed a few months back, all I heard was opposition to a switch to 923 by the locals down there. Also, when was the vote held? I don't see any vote by the community for this HIP on https://heliumvote.com/
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/08/2022 4:05 PM
(To be clear, none of this affects me directly, but I still care about our folks in the affected areas. )
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
but there was zero opposition to the process.
Odd... When this was first being discussed a few months back, all I heard was opposition to a switch to 923 by the locals down there. Also, when was the vote held? I don't see any vote by the community for this HIP on https://heliumvote.com/
louis 03/08/2022 4:06 PM
It was brought up on a few community calls started in Oct and discussion was open here. It was ratified formally in February because there was zero opposition to HIP45 which was the process for changing a frequency plan for any country. This channel is now discussing the first use of HIP45 on switching AU+NZ to AS923-1. I think there are valid arguments to be made to improve HIP45, but I would encourage people to contribute and develop process instead of claiming (unfairly in my opinion) that the process is designed to railroad anyone. I think there are valid arguments to be made against changing AU+NZ to AS923-1 as well, but again, I would encourage people to focus on facts. I've heard numerous corporate conspiracy theories being raised by people against the proposal, but there is zero evidence for this. With the exception of the first DeWi Community Call (which we lost due to being zoom noobs), every discussion and vote regarding the frequency plan was recorded and released publicly. Yet people are going to pretend like there's some corporate take-over happening despite the fact that 1 hotspot = 1 vote. We could be focused on building the best global LoRaWAN Network and how we can frame the AS923-1 vs AU915 debate in that framework. Instead, many community members against the change insist on fabricating a non-fact-based image of other party's nefarious intents. It's completely detrimental to the objective of building a strong IoT network that unifies tech businesses, individuals, farms, government, etc. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/08/2022 4:09 PM
Not to side track, but "1 hotspot = 1 vote"? Where? We've been voting via HNT recently.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Not to side track, but "1 hotspot = 1 vote"? Where? We've been voting via HNT recently.
louis 03/08/2022 4:09 PM

louis

louis 03/08/2022 4:12 PM
It depends on the hardware, but generally, the physical front-ends are identical and firmware/software changes dictate the behavior. However, that doesn't imply that the devices are certified in AU+NZ to use the alternate frequencies (edited)
16:13
That being said, we did recommend back in September before many manufacturers started shipping that they dual-certify. I'm investigating status on that right now

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/08/2022 4:35 PM
The first part of the github:
On December 10th, 2021, during the third meeting of DeWi‚Äôs LoRaWAN Working Group, members voted to initiate a change of frequency plan for Australia and New Zealand from AU915 to AS923-1. The vote count was 3 for and 2 abstentions. The video and minutes of the meeting are available. On February 8th, HIP45 was formally approved and this PR formally initiates the change and begins the 4-week period for written discussion.
Makes it sound like it's all done and the actual implementation is in progress.

louis 03/08/2022 4:37 PM
"begins the 4-week period for written discussion" i communicated it, but I will add the point about the vote at the end
16:37
thanks for the feedback (edited)
1
16:39
On February 8th, HIP45 was formally approved and this PR formally initiates the change and begins the minimum of 4 weeks period for written discussion. After this period, if formal dissent to the change is lodged, a virtual town hall will be held. If there is no resolution, an on-chain vote will be held where one hotspot in the affected region is given one vote. (edited)
1
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/08/2022 4:39 PM
Yeah, I think a lot is the "HIP45 was formally approved" that makes it sound like it's a done deal.
louis 03/08/2022 4:39 PM
hopefully that clarifies ^
louis
On February 8th, HIP45 was formally approved and this PR formally initiates the change and begins the minimum of 4 weeks period for written discussion. After this period, if formal dissent to the change is lodged, a virtual town hall will be held. If there is no resolution, an on-chain vote will be held where one hotspot in the affected region is given one vote. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/08/2022 4:39 PM
That helps a lot

louis 03/10/2022 12:47 PM
The spec is right here: https://lora-alliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/RP002-1.0.3-FINAL-1.pdf You can read: Max EIRP (default) in table 1.3.1 The default may be overriden when provisioning any device to take advantage of local regulations

Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/10/2022 12:57 PM

And processing power which would decrease device lifespan(battery) (edited)
Leo üá¶üá∫
That is not what was said. An AS923 device that hasn't been modified outside of the AS923-1 specs will never join in such remote environments as regional Australia.
louis 03/10/2022 12:58 PM
You made no such caveats in your original statement
l34rn3d
And extra code on devices already under severe space constraints.
louis 03/10/2022 1:00 PM
I've written embedded firmware for over a decade and I can assure you this extra configuration costs very little. Most vendors are likely using the LoramacNode library which likely includes a configuration variable for it, but I can't say for sure on this particular feature.
l34rn3d 03/10/2022 1:01 PM
And if a device was reconfigured for Australian power limits, how would it roam between Australia and other networks legally (edited)
louis
I've written embedded firmware for over a decade and I can assure you this extra configuration costs very little. Most vendors are likely using the LoramacNode library which likely includes a configuration variable for it, but I can't say for sure on this particular feature.
l34rn3d 03/10/2022 1:01 PM
Fair point
l34rn3d
And if a device was reconfigured for Australian power limits, how would it roam between Australia and other networks legally (edited)
louis 03/10/2022 1:04 PM
If you are only using your local Helium Network on AS923-1 (should the change hypothetically take affect of course), it wouldn't matter much. If you intended on roaming outside of the Australian radio jurisdiction, then you have a challenge of either throttling down your device remotely or transmitting at 16dBm and not worrying about it. It seems like most contesting this change have no interest in roaming outside of Australian jurisdiction though so they could take advantage of 30dBm and not worry.
louis
If you are only using your local Helium Network on AS923-1 (should the change hypothetically take affect of course), it wouldn't matter much. If you intended on roaming outside of the Australian radio jurisdiction, then you have a challenge of either throttling down your device remotely or transmitting at 16dBm and not worrying about it. It seems like most contesting this change have no interest in roaming outside of Australian jurisdiction though so they could take advantage of 30dBm and not worry.
l34rn3d 03/10/2022 1:06 PM
That's a key point in the PR, is roaming ability if I for instance wanted to track something from Indonesia to Australia remote outback this device would then be useless (edited)
louis 03/10/2022 1:07 PM
And just to be clear, I truly don't have a side on this. I earnestly believe both sides have fair arguments and to me (if i had a vote), it would come down to which freq plan brings the most traffic to the network. The only reason I'm presenting AS923-1 talking points is to clarify certain misconceptions that are being spread about the arguments. I'm an engineer first and foremost and playing devil's advocate is a reflex.
louis
You made no such caveats in your original statement
Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/10/2022 1:07 PM
Because for all practical intents users that buy devices will have no idea. They will get a device that does not work.
l34rn3d
That's a key point in the PR, is roaming ability if I for instance wanted to track something from Indonesia to Australia remote outback this device would then be useless (edited)
louis 03/10/2022 1:09 PM
Yes, the central argument is that roaming will be easier with neighboring countries that have AS923-1. Dynamically throttling power output or transmitting at a lower level is much more practical than jumping between frequency plans for an end device.
louis
And just to be clear, I truly don't have a side on this. I earnestly believe both sides have fair arguments and to me (if i had a vote), it would come down to which freq plan brings the most traffic to the network. The only reason I'm presenting AS923-1 talking points is to clarify certain misconceptions that are being spread about the arguments. I'm an engineer first and foremost and playing devil's advocate is a reflex.
Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/10/2022 1:10 PM
For an "independent" person I hear precious little about the effect on what is a perfectly working system. This change is proposing to replace a perfectly working system fit for purpose in this country with something that needs tweaks to make it work.
l34rn3d
That's a key point in the PR, is roaming ability if I for instance wanted to track something from Indonesia to Australia remote outback this device would then be useless (edited)
louis 03/10/2022 1:11 PM
for instance wanted to track something from Indonesia to Australia remote outback this device would then be useless
I don't quite follow? I'd be in trouble with AU915 because I'd have to detect the change in jurisdition and adapt dynamically. With AS923-1 i could persistently transmit at 16dBm OR implement some logic to adjust. The logic for adjusting here seems ok to me as you can track your device and when it hits a hotspot of another jurisdiction make the change. But with AU915/AS923, I have to realize that nobody hears me and dynamically jump. It's much more complex, IMO
Leo üá¶üá∫
For an "independent" person I hear precious little about the effect on what is a perfectly working system. This change is proposing to replace a perfectly working system fit for purpose in this country with something that needs tweaks to make it work.
louis 03/10/2022 1:13 PM
I fundamentally believe that we need to build a system and governance that provides mechanisms for change, otherwise, we remain stagnant and become deprecated. Technology and the world changes. HIP45 provides that while allowing operators to reject the change if it is too disruptive or not seen worth adopting.
louis
Yes, the central argument is that roaming will be easier with neighboring countries that have AS923-1. Dynamically throttling power output or transmitting at a lower level is much more practical than jumping between frequency plans for an end device.

Sydney Water to deploy thousands more IoT sensors
Exclusive: Reveals push into AI, development of digital twins.
14:20
That one suggest initial talks were with TTN
14:21
https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.tenders.nsw.gov.au/%3Fevent%3Dpublic.RFT.downloadSummary%26rftuuid%3D8633479D-D5EE-B22D-90FB14469C2DD4A5&ved=2ahUKEwjQmYXwybz2AhVeUWwGHcPHDHQQFnoECA4QAQ&usg=AOvVaw2WfJeiyhKR1R8XpxjcRIGT
14:22
3.1 Network It is mandatory that devices use an NB-IoT/CAT-M1 modem for network communication. The communication module used must be Telstra certified. Where the module supports both technologies, the user must be able to switch/use either mode. It is desirable that a LoRaWAN variant of the device be available which could be deployed in areas of poor cellular network coverage. It is anticipated however that any LoRaWAN variant would only be deployed in very small numbers. For LoRaWAN devices it is mandatory that the devices support AS923. It is highly desirable that they can transmit at +19dBm or greater output power. Devices with an option for IoT Satellite connectivity may also be considered for this subset.
l34rn3d
3.1 Network It is mandatory that devices use an NB-IoT/CAT-M1 modem for network communication. The communication module used must be Telstra certified. Where the module supports both technologies, the user must be able to switch/use either mode. It is desirable that a LoRaWAN variant of the device be available which could be deployed in areas of poor cellular network coverage. It is anticipated however that any LoRaWAN variant would only be deployed in very small numbers. For LoRaWAN devices it is mandatory that the devices support AS923. It is highly desirable that they can transmit at +19dBm or greater output power. Devices with an option for IoT Satellite connectivity may also be considered for this subset.

Public network operators - Helium (5000+ gateways) - exactly 5003 gateways as of early this morning. - TTN (~400 gateways) Private operators - Fleet Space - GeoWAN - Senet/SimplyCity
16:45

A decision that was not well researched at all and had no considerate debate nor any involvement from the community. I know we both are trying to achieve the best outcome for Helium. I would urge you however to spend some time fact checking the information underlying the committee decision and have some regard for the Australian Helium operators who are totally united in this.

louis 03/13/2022 5:34 PM
Complaining about 'disingenous' statements works only if you don't keep peddling them yourself
In the scroll-back, you imply that devices cannot transmit at 30 dBm on AS923-1 in Australia [1]. I call your statement disingenuous because you've already acknowledged that it is "theoretically possible" [2]. That you think it's impractical because you have to do some level of configuration before deploying a device is a different matter. I provided evidence that you are wrong by referring to the specification [3]. You then try to walk back the claim with caveats after the fact [4], but you did no such thing in your initial statement, which as it stood, was spreading misinformation. [1] https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/908961947830071316/951579139381530706 [2] https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/311#issuecomment-1059944198 [3] https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/908961947830071316/951582195196231732 [4] https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/908961947830071316/951582195196231732 You now have the gall to make baseless accusations about me after I generally ask that people wishing to engage in debate do not make public conjecture about another entity's motivations without evidence [5]. I told you in particular to please stop [6]. It's fine if you don't believe me when I say that I don't have a strong technical preference between AS923-1/AU915 [7], but you absolutely cannot spread that baseless accusation that's in direct conflict of what my stated position is. While I cannot prove my intent, you certainly cannot and it is absolutely unacceptable to parade around a community making unprovable claims about every other person's agenda. [5] https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hplans/pull/28#issuecomment-1063381611 [6] https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hplans/pull/28#issuecomment-1063502050 [7] https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/908961947830071316/951587006562050128
I know we both are trying to achieve the best outcome for Helium.
You have antagonized several people in the community. Your behavior is way outside of any norms for collaborative communities such as this one. I am recommending you be banned by DeWi's moderators. (edited)

[5] https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hplans/pull/28#issuecomment-1063381611 [6] https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hplans/pull/28#issuecomment-1063502050 [7] https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/908961947830071316/951587006562050128
I know we both are trying to achieve the best outcome for Helium.
You have antagonized several people in the community. Your behavior is way outside of any norms for collaborative communities such as this one. I am recommending you be banned by DeWi's moderators. (edited)
AJCrom 03/13/2022 6:44 PM
Wow . I‚Äôm not a technical guy , I‚Äôm a business guy attempting to build a business around Helium . There seems to be a lot of noise around this but I come back to the fundamental questions / observations : - this proposal seems to have no technical merit or outcome that will improve the Helium network in Australia . What it will mean is a requirement to reprogram gateways and sensors , a reduction in coverage and create massive uncertainty in the business community . - there is no clear answer on who is driving this change and why it‚Äôs being done . When I asked this , Louis said he was speaking to some unnamed companies about this but he could not reveal who they were . I think this is where the uncertainty / questions then are raised within the Australian community about motives . Banning someone with a contrary view ( and from what I‚Äôve read is not antagonistic , just disagreeable ) is not the right course of action .

Complaining about 'disingenous' statements works only if you don't keep peddling them yourself
In the scroll-back, you imply that devices cannot transmit at 30 dBm on AS923-1 in Australia [1]. I call your statement disingenuous because you've already acknowledged that it is "theoretically possible" [2]. That you think it's impractical because you have to do some level of configuration before deploying a device is a different matter. I provided evidence that you are wrong by referring to the specification [3]. You then try to walk back the claim with caveats after the fact [4], but you did no such thing in your initial statement, which as it stood, was spreading misinformation. Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/13/2022 7:58 PM
If any of this has caused personal offence I am happy to apologise for that as it was certainly not the intention. I am also happy to leave any questions or observations as to people's motivations aside and let everyone come to their own conclusions. However on the substance of mistruths or 'disingenuous statements,' it is fair to ask for corrections from both sides. I have replied to this statement of yours: "TTN is the only other one on AU915 that I‚Äôve heard." We had this conversation in the community call and this has been corrected on the Github PR the same day it was posted. The fact is that there are at least 5 current AU915 operators in Australia. And I have made efforts to actually verify this. You have completely ignored this in your reply. As for the AS923 max TX power, it is still correct that the default configuration for this frequency plan is 16dBm (as per LoRa Alliance Regional Parameter specs). The statement that this can be changed on the device is not me walking backwards. It is the proponents of the AS923 stating that each device would need to be modified to work differently in Australia (which was not mentioned at all in PR28). Which I still believe is impractical and not realistic to actually happen in the real world. I am sure this will be discussed at length at the town hall meeting. And lastly to clarify the comment that I am "not making any constructive suggestions". I am working on a HIP proposal to ensure that these committee decisions can not happen again in future. The fact that I am of the firm belief that remaining with a perfectly workable AU915 frequency plan over one that will require massive work on gateway owners and device owners to actually work in Australia does not mean it is a less constructive solution.

The issue being. Many of us do not watch every video, read every hip and comment, so this change could have simply gone unknown to the larger community. Until it was motioned, at which point thousands of existing au915 devices would become paperweights for no reason, until such a time someone updates the firmware manually on the devices. (edited)

louis 03/14/2022 12:53 AM
heliumvote.com is recent and so far has been applied to HIPs deemed controversial, I believe. In fact, the use of heliumvote.com to resolve a freq plan change in HIP45 (but votes being counted by impacted hotspots instead of HNT) follows precisely the same pattern of only deploying the vote under some standard of controversy. There was no controversy during the 5 months HIP45 was open and the straw poll was clearly for, therefore, accepted by DeWi. You can see the straw poll here: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/908961947830071316/915600300822372352 After the straw poll, most messages were, in fact, requests for a frequency plan change, which highlights the need for a process around this. Once we applied HIP45 to AU+NZ, there has obviously been a lot of displeasure in the process, but where was no such feedback during the 5 month period between HIP opening and acceptance. Hardly a ‚Äúshoving through‚Äù allowing nearly half a year for feedback. The logic ‚Äúno vote, not valid‚Äù would basically dismiss 80% of accepted HIPs by my guesstimate. You‚Äôre free to make a tally yourself but, in my opinion, that logic would greatly set the network back and create unnecessary work as we need to re-ratify dozens of HIPs.
l34rn3d 03/14/2022 1:08 AM
So hip 45 is active. And the process to change frequencys per hip45 is being used. And if there was no disagreement with the suggested changes. This would have passed without a vote, or town hall. correct?
l34rn3d
So hip 45 is active. And the process to change frequencys per hip45 is being used. And if there was no disagreement with the suggested changes. This would have passed without a vote, or town hall. correct?
louis 03/14/2022 1:30 AM
Yes, if there had been no ‚Äúformal dissent‚Äù, the recommendation to change frequency is accepted without a town hall and without the ensuing vote (assuming no side withdraws after town hall). There are dozens of frequency plan changes being requested and discussed - most are not as controversial as the current proposal for AU+NZ, so the intent was to allow those to proceed with minimal delay (4 weeks) while ensuring operators cannot be dragged towards a change against their will since the final vote is theirs.
1
CI | 1Solo | (33.3%)
Before & after numbers on the same hotspot pre & post pocv11

jamiedubs 03/14/2022 6:25 AM
the heliumvote.com website is not and has never been a binding vote, and so far has only been used on disputed topics. imho it would be impossible to make them binding as-is, since there is often little to no code written when these votes happen; there are other proposals like #hip-41-governance-by-token-lock-v2 that suggest making this process binding HIP45 (as a process) was under development and discussion for months and was decidedly uncontroversial, per my note
06:26
this particular frequency decision (using the HIP45 process) is another matter

Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/14/2022 10:47 PM
Just to be clear. There is a big difference between "making up stories" and asking questions about people's motivation. In absence of any answers to these questions forthcoming, all that is available is having to draw conclusions from all the evidence at hand. Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/14/2022 10:55 PM
I would like to add some further questions on this "roaming argument" that keeps being mentioned in conjunction with this AS923-1 vote on the LoRa committee. Where are these "regional roaming use-cases"? I work on LoRaWAN both in Australia and in Europe since 2016. I know LoRaWAN GLOBAL ROAMING will be an issue one day. But it is NEVER going to be solved by switching a country's frequency plan (as different countries have different regulations). There are companies right now testing roaming LoRaWAN devices. But these are SDR devices will switch frequency plan according to the country they detect themselves in. That is the ONLY WAY you will ever get true roaming. Changing the network to suit some device is the tail wagging the dog. The frequency plan should be chosen to be the BEST FOR THE COUNTRY it is serving. Even if there would be some of these "roaming use-cases". People COULD ROAM RIGHT NOW. Two (New Zealand and Papua New Guinea) of the three neighbouring countries (more if you want to count the Antarctic territories) as they are all already on AU915. The only other neighbour (and the largest - Indonesia) we would not be able to roam with in any case as they are on AU923-3. Fact is that if roaming were an issue - you can do this right now - without downgrading a whole country of 5000+ operators. Making up spurious "benefits" does not make them valid. And and stating them over and over again also does not make them come true. Can we please get someone to provide some evidence as to who is actually requesting this as a need? What are their use-cases?
22:56
Unfortunately I am unable to add this on the Github PR (where it would belong) as it appears I have been blocked from the DEWI Github Repo. I have posted this here in the interest of an open discussion.
1
Leo üá¶üá∫
Just to be clear. There is a big difference between "making up stories" and asking questions about people's motivation. In absence of any answers to these questions forthcoming, all that is available is having to draw conclusions from all the evidence at hand. And if you care to read all the various threads I am certainly not the only one asking these questions as well as reaching those conclusions. And I will leave it at that and others can judge by themselves. I stand by what I have written and I have made clear multiple times that none of this was intended to be taken personal. Do you have a link to these guidelines I could read?
louis 03/15/2022 12:47 AM
We generally abide by these guidelines in Helium open source repositories: https://www.contributor-covenant.org/ It appears we've omitted it's endorsement in hplans repo. By my judgement, you have violated the first two bullets: * Demonstrating empathy and kindness toward other people * Being respectful of differing opinions, viewpoints, and experiences Despite our omission in posting standard open-source contribution guidelines, I warned you explicitly to stop using conjecture to discuss someone motives. It is disrespectful of the differing technical opinion and equates to an ad hominem attack . This is now the third time, I explain to you: We all have limited time and there is no burden to deny a claim that itself is without evidence. I wish I had time to address some of the other great points & questions here but instead I find myself repeatedly asking people to simply be curteous & factual. Yet just now again, it seems you feel entitled: There is a big difference between "making up stories" and asking questions about people's motivation. In absence of any answers to these questions forthcoming, all that is available is having to draw conclusions from all the evidence at hand. Your behavior is making the environment uncomfortable for other people who would like to engage on the topic for its technical merits, as they would have to worry about your hurling conjecture at them right and left. And your persistence today really reflects on the sincerity of yesterday's apology.

Here is an early draft of our HIP proposal as per Github discussion with @jamiedubs & @louis on HIP-45 (https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/357#issuecomment-1057533423). This is to socialise the concept and seek community feedback (in order of preference): 1. by forking this repo and submitting a pull request (preferred!!!) 2. by creating a Github issue in the repository 3. Discord feedback DRAFT LoRaWAN Committee HIP: https://github.com/leogaggl/HIP/blob/main/00XX-lorawan-committee.md

Maybe that's just me, I'm used to the military aviation environment also, which whether it's with Americans, Europeans or Aussies is extremely frank and to the point but again is never an attack on the person just an analysis of what went wrong on the mission so that we can all learn. Maybe I'm just missing it, but I don't see anything directed against you personally.
louis 03/17/2022 7:10 PM
However, I will say, the contribution covenant i cited is not culturally specific. It is universally adopted in open source communities regardless of borders. If Australians pride themselves on being abrasive it is not really a reason to adjust it, since so many international technical communities adopt it as a standard for communication that allows for expression of opinion.
Jules22 03/17/2022 7:11 PM
No, but the perception of what is an attack or hostility is certainly culturally and individually specific, like I have said I haven't seen anything that rises to that level from the people who are asking questions and posting reasons against the proposal (edited)

vudu 03/18/2022 12:45 AM
Hi Guys and Gals, thought I'd stick my head in to see how we were progressing. I know you are trying but... Not sure if anyone noticed my previous question. Was hoping for a concise, considered and technically robust answer. Got crickets. I've read as much of the published literature as I could fathom, was a little dry. Perhaps if I trim some adjectives? Beyond the motivation of some perceived technical unity, why the effort (let call this "human expenditure") to fix (break) a system that is perfectly fit for purpose? I believe the question to be relevant, in good faith, aligned with contributor covenants, and unlikely to contravene contribution guidelines. TIA
1
vudu 03/18/2022 1:41 AM
Let me try a little harder. From the GH submission:- Four large public operators... Seems to lack relevance and ignore the wishes of the wider community. Roaming with other countries... Achievable as built into the device? Seemingly so. Large organisations are requesting AS923-1 ... Again, How relevant to a public network? What prevents organisation building their own compatability. Downlink coverage on AS923-1 has 6dB... Seems to have been discussed and refuted by those way smarter than me. AS923-1 is a dynamic channel plan...as the capacity increases or to deal with potential interference Seems to be a non issue from the discussion I have read and can understand. The Join Procedure is faster... Another non issue. I'm (we're) in no hurry. Ask me how long I waited for my hotspot and the industry BS I've witnessed.. So In my view, perhaps defined as that of a punter, and likely the view of the greater supporters, Australian and otherwise, of the network as it stands, we (sic) dictate changes in terms of human and financial expenditure to appease a few minorities that may well have the resources to operate within the public network as it stands. And we asked to support such a decision based on technical arguments seemingly already refuted and devoid of merit. How did we get here? (edited)

Jaytheblader 03/20/2022 8:18 PM
I don't see how changing Australia to AS923 is going to help Brazil (AU915) roam to USA (US915) roam to China (CN470) etc. don't you just need nodes that can automatically change their frequency depending on region for that or am I missing something?
Jules22 03/20/2022 8:20 PM
That is the accepted best practice for roaming systems
Jules22 03/20/2022 8:28 PM
Due to the various regulatory regimes you will never have all countries on the same frequency
20:28
plenty of countries currently stuck on AS923 would love to be on AU915
1
Jaytheblader
I don't see how changing Australia to AS923 is going to help Brazil (AU915) roam to USA (US915) roam to China (CN470) etc. don't you just need nodes that can automatically change their frequency depending on region for that or am I missing something?
Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/20/2022 8:29 PM
Roaming in the sense that is used in this press release doesn't actually have anything to do with what people think of in terms of regional roaming (which of course you are right that changing a frequency plan will never solve global roaming). All this is about is that devices using the Actility network can "roam" onto Helium network (within the same country). And there wouldn't be anything wrong with this at all. In fact it's a good thing where Helium is on the same frequency plan. The problem is that in Australia they changed the frequency plan for the whole country as the two operators using the Actility network chose the Asian frequency plan years ago. Effectively throwing the whole country under the bus by downgrading the network now and for the future.
Leo üá¶üá∫
Roaming in the sense that is used in this press release doesn't actually have anything to do with what people think of in terms of regional roaming (which of course you are right that changing a frequency plan will never solve global roaming). All this is about is that devices using the Actility network can "roam" onto Helium network (within the same country). And there wouldn't be anything wrong with this at all. In fact it's a good thing where Helium is on the same frequency plan. The problem is that in Australia they changed the frequency plan for the whole country as the two operators using the Actility network chose the Asian frequency plan years ago. Effectively throwing the whole country under the bus by downgrading the network now and for the future.

gradoj 03/29/2022 1:37 PM
Having two valid channel plans is a good thing not a negative. If there is a public network that wants to roam on helium that is excellent and should be embraced. There has been endless discussion on technical superiority of au915-most of which really dont matter imo until years from now when there are dense numbers of sensors. If there is a hybrid solution that is being proposed that can leverage both bands that is brilliant and id like to see the technical proposal. My understanding is all hotspots are compatible either way so there will be no hardware obsoleted. Not being from Australia this has little impact on me but turning your nose at a roaming partner potentially hurts all of helium. I certainly agree with the technical experts and Dewi advocating/pushing a direction they believe will most benefit the network (edited)
gradoj

gradoj
Having two valid channel plans is a good thing not a negative. If there is a public network that wants to roam on helium that is excellent and should be embraced. There has been endless discussion on technical superiority of au915-most of which really dont matter imo until years from now when there are dense numbers of sensors. If there is a hybrid solution that is being proposed that can leverage both bands that is brilliant and id like to see the technical proposal. My understanding is all hotspots are compatible either way so there will be no hardware obsoleted. Not being from Australia this has little impact on me but turning your nose at a roaming partner potentially hurts all of helium. I certainly agree with the technical experts and Dewi advocating/pushing a direction they believe will most benefit the network (edited)
Jules22 03/29/2022 1:48 PM
Definitely agree, that's why I am so keen to hear more technical detail on how this would be possible. I'm not sure how 923 can be supported without compromising 915, but I'd be very happy to be proven wrong! I also don't agree that the clearly inferior standard be 'advertised' as the default. Common sense would dictate that the superior frequency is the only choice as far as the official standard, with 923 being supported if that is possible.

Pavle 03/29/2022 1:58 PM
I don't disagree with your sentiment and looking from the outside in, I concur, this looks like a good arrangement to leverage both bands. The issue for me is quantifying the demand to roam on the 923 frequency. From the research currently available, this is minimal. Without evidence of the number of sensors / devices currently in place / proposed, it's impossible to support any change. We all know 915 devices are superior and will absolutely be the future, particularly in a country as large as Australia where the distance between major centers is huge. We also have a significant agriculture industry that is already benefiting from the 915 solution and the phenomenal coverage it can provide with fewer gateways.
4
Pavle
I don't disagree with your sentiment and looking from the outside in, I concur, this looks like a good arrangement to leverage both bands. The issue for me is quantifying the demand to roam on the 923 frequency. From the research currently available, this is minimal. Without evidence of the number of sensors / devices currently in place / proposed, it's impossible to support any change. We all know 915 devices are superior and will absolutely be the future, particularly in a country as large as Australia where the distance between major centers is huge. We also have a significant agriculture industry that is already benefiting from the 915 solution and the phenomenal coverage it can provide with fewer gateways.
Jules22 03/29/2022 2:01 PM
This is another very good point, much has been made of 1 or 2 operators using legacy 923 devices, but there are many more using 915 in Australia. There has been no quantified demonstrable data presented showing any benefit to accommodating 923. Now if this can be done without any compromise to 915, then that isn't such a big issue, but if there is to be ANY degradation to 915 coverage then this does need to be justified.
3
14:08
It should also be noted that the main projects which have been quoted as a reason for the move so far are all in pre-tender and trial stages. They are looking to run trials with multiple technologies from multiple vendors so this argument seems extremely premature. It is much more likely that those projects will settle on the superior technology as the majority of other upcoming projects in Australia already have. (edited)

Jules22 03/29/2022 3:53 PM
This is the crux of the problem, HIP 45 has been shown to be flawed, the governance and process is clearly not fit for purpose and in this case even the scarce processes in place (such as the 28 day consultation period) were not followed. The only proper outcome at this point is to have this proposal completely shelved until a proper process can be put in place and the proposal be properly evaluated. So much time has been spent and wasted on a proposal for a 'pie in the sky' promise of winning contracts that are not decided yet, using a inferior technology that is clearly on it's way out in Australia. (edited)

Pavle 03/29/2022 4:06 PM
I am only a hobbyist with a single hotspot so don't have a lot of skin in the game here, and I have personally called my fellow Aussies to tone it down and focus on the technical aspects of the debate as I've seen some comments that I feel would be better left unsaid. In saying that, I also understand the frustration and aggression that may come across in the styles of writing employed (sometimes due to differences in how language is perceived and other times just pure condescending). This is not the first time this change has been raised and I believe it's on record that it was a less than ideal proposal then. For it to reappear in a way that can only be described as by stealth, weather that was intentional or not is unknown, however it's certainly been perceived that way and no one from dewi or Helium has made any effort to correct this on record. All that is required here is for all of the facts to be presented openly and honestly so everyone can be on the same page and I am sure this will go a long way to allowing the debate to remain on topic and without emotion - that is unless the facts support the perception that this is a dud deal.

Just to clarify, there may be some confusion, HIP 45 is the process to decide on frequency changes, not the specific change for AUS. The change for AUS definitely should be scrapped, HIP 45 can be improved/modified so that these sorts of issues don't happen again. We are at an impasse where we are debating something that doesn't exist, there is no solid plan. I would be very confident that the amount of damage caused by the uncertainty which has dragged on so long as a result has cost the network more than any potential benefit that may have come from bringing these 923 devices onto the network.

Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/29/2022 7:00 PM
AU915 and AS923 have been in use for quite some time and the evidence is out there I believe. Both in theory and in practice. We have had plenty of examples of people having to change back from AS923 to AU915 in regional use cases as the coverage was not sufficient. And it has been quite well outlined in the PR. That decision could be made with confidence I would say. I have no idea what the proposal now is in detail. But it would probably safe to say nothing of this nature has been tried anywhere. But that can only be answered by @louis & team.

What is Osborne Effect? - Definition from WhatIs.com

Jules22 03/30/2022 2:28 PM
Hmm so this is troubling. If HIP 45 was passed with only ~30 people showing any interest, one would have to assume that a large portion of those 30 were involved in the project. Further, it would suggest, which I know from talking to people, that the vast majority (possibly well over 90%) of the Helium community had no idea about HIP45 prior to it being 'passed'. Even more troubling, had there been full transparency on the decision from December and how HIP 45 was intended to be used to push through a change that had already been rejected as being bad for the network, I'm sure the level of interest in HIP 45 would have been dramatically higher. This whole process has been a cascade of oversights, poor transparency, failures to follow procedural fairness. It is an extremely bad look for Helium and I honestly think the only recourse is to take a complete step back and re-evaluate the whole process even back to the formation of HIP45. The more facts that come out, the worse this continues to look. The process has already created significant damage in Australia and it is starting to be noticed more and more internationally. Helium faces a PR disaster if this mess is not cleaned up. (edited)

louis 03/30/2022 3:33 PM
I've been on calls with a utility in Australia and another company that wanted to use it, so I put it on the first LoRaWAN Committee agenda back in Sept, where 5/5 voted for it. And again in December, where 3/5 voted for it.
15:34
the whole principle was we get inbound from people who say they'd like a different frequency plan, so by passing the idea through the committee, many of which are on the LoRaWAN Alliance board, we can steer the network into something that aligns with the rest of the ecosystem
Jules22 03/30/2022 3:35 PM
I thought the idea was that there is a community member who proposes the change and then participates in the 28 day discussion period where both sides can present their argument and give either side the opportunity to withdraw/modify their request/opposition. To date we've heard nothing from the "other side" so I'm wondering who it is and why they have not had any engagement per the stipulated process?
Jules22
I thought the idea was that there is a community member who proposes the change and then participates in the 28 day discussion period where both sides can present their argument and give either side the opportunity to withdraw/modify their request/opposition. To date we've heard nothing from the "other side" so I'm wondering who it is and why they have not had any engagement per the stipulated process?
louis 03/30/2022 3:41 PM
The idea of HIP45 was to respond to the backlash in September when the committee initially made the recommendation. So the design is: (1) committee makes a recommendation (2) hotspot owners in region have the power to veto the change The minimum 28 day window is meant for discussion and I agree its been one-sided. I've made my opinion about the tone of the discussion pretty clear in the past and, from my perspective, I'm not terribly surprised that people who are for the change don't see much point in having casual conversation on the GitHub thread. The LoRaWAN Committee will provide more written details soon. I also want it to be sooner than later. (edited)
1
louis

Jules22 03/30/2022 5:53 PM

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/30/2022 6:09 PM
Doh, I can see Sc0tt's "family leave" message now. Sorry about the ping.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
Perhaps @scott would be the right person to bring into the conversation
scott 03/30/2022 6:29 PM
I'll be honest, I am extremely tired. Today took a lot out of me and I have a newborn at home. I covered some of this in today's AMA with respect to governance but I'll echo it here. Blockchain governance is extremely difficult for a general smart contract chain -- we have even more complexity. To date, the Foundation has been taking an ad-hoc approach to committees while designing a more holistic and scalable system. We've optimized for decision-making over extensive deliberation for the sake of momentum. That will naturally yield some imperfection. With the case of the LoRaWAN committee, we believed that large operators gave us the best insight into large deployments and the direction of the market. Should the local market in question have been consulted? Certainly. This is the downside of an open network -- we learn in public and it can get contentious. There's a balance of stakeholder input to be determined for this issue as well as others, but as PoC rewards taper off and the economic incentive for hosts more heavily relies on DC use, I don't think it's inappropriate to favor opinions from the largest LoRaWAN operators and users since they're a meaningful input to Network value. I'm not disregarding potential conflicts, I'm repeating above that we optimized for decision-making. Fwiw, we have someone actively doing research on AS923 vs AU915 traffic. I do not personally have any of that data yet. Going forward, the Foundation is working on a public draft including guidelines on committee formation, initial appointments, voting, etc so there's more consistency and expectations are better managed. I was personally more hands-on with the formation and appointments of the MOC so I apologize if I haven't been able to give the LoRaWAN committee enough attention. I do appreciate the work that's been done here https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/378 and will speak to it more soon. I believe that was @Leo 🇦🇺 and others? Lmk who should be appropriately acknowledged. I'm simply replying to acknowledge the issue, that it has my & HF's attention, and improvements need to be made. You can expect I'll come back with more input by the April 11th/12th town hall at the latest. If there's new data to share, it will be made available -- this should be a collaborative process. We're ultimately all in this together For now this is still the Foundation's position: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/813452716286017557/958171404149338112 (edited)
9
3
scott
I'll be honest, I am extremely tired. Today took a lot out of me and I have a newborn at home. I covered some of this in today's AMA with respect to governance but I'll echo it here. Blockchain governance is extremely difficult for a general smart contract chain -- we have even more complexity. To date, the Foundation has been taking an ad-hoc approach to committees while designing a more holistic and scalable system. We've optimized for decision-making over extensive deliberation for the sake of momentum. That will naturally yield some imperfection. With the case of the LoRaWAN committee, we believed that large operators gave us the best insight into large deployments and the direction of the market. Should the local market in question have been consulted? Certainly. This is the downside of an open network -- we learn in public and it can get contentious. There's a balance of stakeholder input to be determined for this issue as well as others, but as PoC rewards taper off and the economic incentive for hosts more heavily relies on DC use, I don't think it's inappropriate to favor opinions from the largest LoRaWAN operators and users since they're a meaningful input to Network value. I'm not disregarding potential conflicts, I'm repeating above that we optimized for decision-making. Fwiw, we have someone actively doing research on AS923 vs AU915 traffic. I do not personally have any of that data yet. Going forward, the Foundation is working on a public draft including guidelines on committee formation, initial appointments, voting, etc so there's more consistency and expectations are better managed. I was personally more hands-on with the formation and appointments of the MOC so I apologize if I haven't been able to give the LoRaWAN committee enough attention. I do appreciate the work that's been done here https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/378 and will speak to it more soon. I believe that was @Leo 🇦🇺 and others? Lmk who should be appropriately acknowledged. I'm simply replying to acknowledge the issue, that it has my & HF's attention, and improvements need to be made. You can expect I'll come back with more input by the April 11th/12th town hall at the latest. If there's new data to share, it will be made available -- this should be a collaborative process. We're ultimately all in this together For now this is still the Foundation's position: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/813452716286017557/958171404149338112 (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/30/2022 6:36 PM
Congrats on the newborn! ‚ù§Ô∏è
5
3
l34rn3d 03/30/2022 6:39 PM
Thanks Scott. Appreciate the reply. And best of luck with the sleep depravation! (edited)
6
scott
I'll be honest, I am extremely tired. Today took a lot out of me and I have a newborn at home. I covered some of this in today's AMA with respect to governance but I'll echo it here. Blockchain governance is extremely difficult for a general smart contract chain -- we have even more complexity. To date, the Foundation has been taking an ad-hoc approach to committees while designing a more holistic and scalable system. We've optimized for decision-making over extensive deliberation for the sake of momentum. That will naturally yield some imperfection. With the case of the LoRaWAN committee, we believed that large operators gave us the best insight into large deployments and the direction of the market. Should the local market in question have been consulted? Certainly. This is the downside of an open network -- we learn in public and it can get contentious. There's a balance of stakeholder input to be determined for this issue as well as others, but as PoC rewards taper off and the economic incentive for hosts more heavily relies on DC use, I don't think it's inappropriate to favor opinions from the largest LoRaWAN operators and users since they're a meaningful input to Network value. I'm not disregarding potential conflicts, I'm repeating above that we optimized for decision-making. Fwiw, we have someone actively doing research on AS923 vs AU915 traffic. I do not personally have any of that data yet. Going forward, the Foundation is working on a public draft including guidelines on committee formation, initial appointments, voting, etc so there's more consistency and expectations are better managed. I was personally more hands-on with the formation and appointments of the MOC so I apologize if I haven't been able to give the LoRaWAN committee enough attention. I do appreciate the work that's been done here https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/378 and will speak to it more soon. I believe that was @Leo 🇦🇺 and others? Lmk who should be appropriately acknowledged. I'm simply replying to acknowledge the issue, that it has my & HF's attention, and improvements need to be made. You can expect I'll come back with more input by the April 11th/12th town hall at the latest. If there's new data to share, it will be made available -- this should be a collaborative process. We're ultimately all in this together For now this is still the Foundation's position: https://discord.com/channels/404106811252408320/813452716286017557/958171404149338112 (edited)
Pavle 03/30/2022 7:43 PM
Hi Scott, congratulations on the newborn and appreciate you taking the time out to convey an update on this situation. I have reached out to some of my fellow Australian community members who have been most active in this channel and proposed that we pull back on the discussion here and allow you some respite to focus on your family. We hope that the information being sought by the team on network traffic can be received, collated and distributed in advance of the meeting to allow all interested parties time to peruse the content and be best prepared for the upcoming townhall. It would also be fantastic if this could be extended to include the quantities of new devices already in tender and the preferred frequency being requested, as this appears to be one of the most contentious issues currently and could be a significant inclusion in the very near-term additional traffic. Any questions we have in the interim, we will try and consolidate so that we aren't all chasing the same answers individually and will put them to you and the team in this channel over the course of the next week or so.

19:44

Leo üá¶üá∫ 03/30/2022 8:47 PM
The only thing I would add/change is not pause. But withdraw and restart under new committee with proper governance. We are trying to belp! Thanks @scott and enjoy time with your newborn!
7
scott 04/01/2022 12:03 PM
For the participants in the HIP-45 channel here. We'll post an agenda for the April 11/12th Town Hall by early next week. The purpose of the discussion is to fairly represent and assess the cases for AS923 and AU915 as a collaborative community. As a reminder, the Foundation is in favor of dual-compatibility from a technical perspective, but believes that a single advertised standard will help reduce fragmentation. The goal of the Town Hall is to find consensus on the advertised standard. If you'd like to participate as a presenter for either regional channel plan: Please email joey@helium.foundation and include 1. A concise summary or bullet points outlining your dissent or support for the change. This will reflect the outline on the town hall agenda. 2. Whether you prefer your remarks to be shared by the moderator or if you request time to speak (we will try to accommodate best as possible). Please consider the time of everyone in attendance and keep your perspective as objective as possible with supporting evidence pertinent to the technical and economic effects of the proposed change. Regarding HIP-45 and Committee governance: This Town Hall will not focus on the HIP-45 framework itself or governance. The urgent issue is providing clarity to prospective Helium Network users and prioritized. Again, the goal is to find some consensus on the issue. The Foundation will be sharing an outline that addresses holistic Committee setup, membership, rules, and voting. You can expect this in April. Much of the proposed Terms of Reference here https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/378, had already been captured in our drafts. Governance will be addressed on a separate call (including the future of the LoRaWAN Committee) for the sake of a narrower scope and more productive discussion.
3
scott pinned a message to this channel. 04/01/2022 12:03 PM
scott
For the participants in the HIP-45 channel here. We'll post an agenda for the April 11/12th Town Hall by early next week. The purpose of the discussion is to fairly represent and assess the cases for AS923 and AU915 as a collaborative community. As a reminder, the Foundation is in favor of dual-compatibility from a technical perspective, but believes that a single advertised standard will help reduce fragmentation. The goal of the Town Hall is to find consensus on the advertised standard. If you'd like to participate as a presenter for either regional channel plan: Please email joey@helium.foundation and include 1. A concise summary or bullet points outlining your dissent or support for the change. This will reflect the outline on the town hall agenda. 2. Whether you prefer your remarks to be shared by the moderator or if you request time to speak (we will try to accommodate best as possible). Please consider the time of everyone in attendance and keep your perspective as objective as possible with supporting evidence pertinent to the technical and economic effects of the proposed change. Regarding HIP-45 and Committee governance: This Town Hall will not focus on the HIP-45 framework itself or governance. The urgent issue is providing clarity to prospective Helium Network users and prioritized. Again, the goal is to find some consensus on the issue. The Foundation will be sharing an outline that addresses holistic Committee setup, membership, rules, and voting. You can expect this in April. Governance will be addressed on a separate call (including the future of the LoRaWAN Committee) for the sake of a narrower scope and more productive discussion.
