For the participants in the HIP-45 channel here. We'll post an agenda for the April 11/12th Town Hall by early next week. The purpose of the discussion is to fairly represent and assess the cases for AS923 and AU915 as a collaborative community. As a reminder, the Foundation is in favor of dual-compatibility from a technical perspective, but believes that a single advertised standard will help reduce fragmentation. The goal of the Town Hall is to find consensus on the advertised standard. If you'd like to participate as a presenter for either regional channel plan: Please email joey@helium.foundation and include 1. A concise summary or bullet points outlining your dissent or support for the change. This will reflect the outline on the town hall agenda. 2. Please consider the time of everyone in attendance and keep your perspective as objective as possible with supporting evidence pertinent to the technical and economic effects of the proposed change. Regarding HIP-45 and Committee governance: This Town Hall will not focus on the HIP-45 framework itself or governance. The urgent issue is providing clarity to prospective Helium Network users and prioritized. Again, the goal is to find some consensus on the issue. The Foundation will be sharing an outline that addresses holistic Committee setup, membership, rules, and voting. You can expect this in April. Jules22 04/01/2022 3:22 PM
Hi @scott, Thanks for the update, but it does not seem to make sense to push through such a hugely controversial and disruptive change under a broken process (which even as broken as it is, was broken further by not being followed) and then look to fix the process after the fact. 1. HIP 45 managed to fly under the radar with only ~30 people showing interest mainly due to the fact that the meeting video from the December meeting were lost for several months. Only appearing after HIP 45 was passed. Had the contents from those meetings been released as per the procedure there would have been dramatically higher levels of interest in HIP45. Given the low level of visibility of the HIP, it should have gone to a vote and this was questioned by a member of the committee in the December meeting where it was floated that it would 'just be passed'. Unfortunately that member was overridden and everything moved on. The only just way forward from this is to withdraw such a controversial proposal until the HIP45 process is fixed.
12
2
15:22
2. It's been acknowledged several times that HIP45 has major issues with transparency, lack of balanced engagement and a lack of technical oversight. This particular proposal has been fraught with issues from the start with 2 of the 3 with technical expertise in the December meeting raising concerns then abstaining from the vote, and the only remaining having a conflict of interest but still being allowed to vote for the proposal (which may not be a problem if it is fully disclosed and other affected parties are also allowed the same participation). The few dot-points which were presented by that member have been extensively rebutted in detail by technical experts. We have also not been told who actually proposed the change only that 'the committee just came up with the idea'. HIP45 is supposed to allow for a 28 day consultation period where both sides can present the arguments for and against and the proposal can be modified or withdrawn as a result. This did not happen 1- because the other party has not identified themselves and has refused to take any part in the consultation period and 2- the forum was shut down for public consultation 2 weeks into the 4 week period. These reasons are more than enough alone to take this back to the beginning and re-evaluate under a fair and balanced system. (edited)
13
3
15:23
3. The proposal for the frequency change for Australia has never been presented in any detail, it has changed 180 degrees from when it was first proposed to now some sort of hybrid scheme which has never been tested and from the answers we have been provided thus far is not even decided on yet. The various potential hybrid options have been covered in detail in the github PR by technical experts and all have been shown to be significantly inferior to best practice systems in place and likely to cause significant disruption to the network now and into the future. No technical counter has been presented by the proponents nor any form of justification to allow for the crippling of the Helium network in Australia. The original proposal is nothing close to the current unformulated proposal and again this reason alone is justification to withdraw the proposal, formulate a detailed plan for how the hybrid system can be achieved and then have that evaluated fully in a fair and balanced system which can then proceed to community consultation etc under a re-vamped HIP45 structure. (edited)
12
2
15:23
These are just three of many reasons why this proposal needs to go back to the drawing board to maintain any semblance of a fair, balanced and transparent process. There have been far too many failures of process, which I am sure are not deliberate, however when added all together you can see why there are many people drawing the conclusion that there has been a concerted effort to push this through via subterfuge. Again I like to look to the positive side and I am not suggesting that this is the case, I can certainly see though how it can appear to be the case to many people. Any fair and proper procedure, particularly one that has the potential to affect the investments of millions of dollars MUST ensure that procedural fairness is maintained in every step. One or two mistakes can be expected in a project of this nature, however this process has been a litany of cascading failures and the goal must be to ensure that there is no appearance (warranted or otherwise) of an unfair or non-transparent process. There is some validity in getting this resolved as soon as possible, however at the same time such a disruptive change needs to be properly evaluated, this cannot be done when the substance of the change has still not been decided. A change of this nature cannot be rushed through. Thank you for your time, I hope you will consider what I have presented. I assure you that I do so with the best intentions with the goal to ensure the longevity of this great project. (edited)
16
gazmcghee 04/01/2022 6:41 PM
@scott "The goal of the Town Hall is to find consensus on the advertised standard." This is a sleight of hand trick. The original goal was to decide whether to change bands or not.

vudu 04/03/2022 2:46 AM
Hi Scott, appreciate your efforts on this. Tough gig indeed. Congrats on the new family addition. And I certainly empathise with regard to adjusting to a whole new sleep pattern. Please don't take what I have to say personally. So as to progress the discussion: We are now to proceed to discuss a case that many, and certailnly the visible stakeholders, would argue, remains lacking in technical merit. And this discussion will proceeed supported by a hip that fails to honour any form of meaningful governance. Has the cart overtaken the horse? If the urgent issue is "providing clarity to prospective Helium Network users" then surely the status quo (and its public reinforcement) achieves that goal more broadly than a proposal that flops around like a dead fish. Consequently this more measured course of action will buy us the time required to put the house in order and move forward with unity and meaningfull governance. What do you think of that? Is this not a sensible plan, likely to garner the broadest of acceptatnce?

Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/03/2022 9:49 PM
Having just returned from a few days outside of cellular coverage I am reading through the last few days and the view of the community is still pretty clear. I agree 100% with the concerns already outlined by a number of people. See @Jules22 excellent summaries. If the aim really is "to fairly represent and assess the cases for AS923 and AU915" we surely have to start with a fair evaluation and comparison between options. This was NEVER done and should have been the first job of this "LoRaWAN committee". You are expecting one side to outline their points 10 days ahead of a town hall. But even after close to 5 weeks of this "written discussion period" we have not had a single explanation or outline from the Helium Foundation or this committee. All we have is constantly moving the goal post and not even adhering to what was outlined in the HIP-45 procedure. All we have are vague announcements with ZERO detail. To any reasonable observer surely the process leading up to this town hall has disqualified this farce to be continued. (edited)

And now we are not even talking about the recommendation from the committee which was outlined in PR-28 (although very sparsely). We are debating some unknown and untried "solution" to a "problem" that only exists for one organisation.

scott 04/05/2022 4:44 PM

4
scott 04/05/2022 7:44 PM
Hey everyone, I reached out to several folks about this matter in the last couple of days and took in multiple perspectives. At this point, on behalf of the Helium Foundation, we'd like to halt any decision or vote that would modify the status quo of AU915 as the default LoRaWAN regional frequency for the Helium Network in Australia or New Zealand. Summarizing some of the points already made by people in this channel: a) There was limited time and discussion ahead of the straw poll b) The straw poll had relatively low participation c) Insufficient meeting notes d) Not fulfilling the nature of the HIP itself (creating the space for the public commentary period and ensuring that someone was owning the process) We will still hold the Town Hall next week as planned, however the purpose will strictly be for information sharing and discovery. The discussion will center around the technical/economic merit for each frequency relative to the region as will best optimize for Network use and roaming. We will record and publicly document the meeting to benefit future discussion if the community decides to pursue a change in the default regional frequency at a later date. Same request as before, email joey@helium.foundation if you want to participate. Now to the governance piece: Under current Helium Network governance HIP-45 is still considered approved (see Github). HIP-45 can be amended and the Foundation is happy to work with anyone on the task. If anything, I welcome it as we've been working on new structures and standards for Network governance. I want to speak to two areas of voiced concern and what we're doing about it. These are (1) HIP Approvals and (2) Committee Structure. It's currently ambiguous what gets an on-chain vote, straw poll, or can pass by rough consensus. We also need documented guidelines on vote passage, and what is decided by the whole community vs a representative group (e.g. MOC). HIP-45 put a spotlight on the ambiguity and we're doing something about it. As I recently mentioned, there's a HIP in draft that will start to standardize several areas of governance, such as various areas of decision making. It will also include a Committee framework for creating a new Committee, required documentation, voting records, and more. The Terms of Reference outlined by Leo overlaps with some of our work. We're not doing this in a vacuum, it'll be public soon. Unfortunately we've genuinely had a lot on our plate but are actively hiring in order to go faster and improve overall comms. Here's what I hope you'll take away from this: 1. That I appreciate the thoughtful, professional contributions to this discussion. The resolve of the community to ensure the Network is successful was very powerful. This is a great thing. 2. I hope everyone making strong cases in a professional manner felt heard (even if it was slower than I preferred) and that there's no unilateral effort to change anything. However we should continue to explore the options collaboratively because later change (if needed) will be more painful. 3. That there's work being done to standardize aspects of governance (voting, committee structure, and reporting) and I look forward to working with some of you on it. I'll be available for a bit here for replies but it's getting late on US east coast. (edited)
13
4
1
Jules22 04/05/2022 7:51 PM
Thanks @scott, it was good chatting with you yesterday, sorry that I had to cut it short. I really appreciate the approach you have taken and I think it will go a long way to restoring confidence from Australian users and investors. I think this is the best approach for the network as a whole long term and am more than willing to help in any way I can. Increasing roaming opportunities and partnerships is definitely a worthy goal and I fully support this as I am sure most will, we just need to ensure that significant changes are fully evaluated and a thorough cost/benefit investigation is done. Thanks Again.
1
scott 04/05/2022 7:54 PM
Thanks @Jules22, with respect to evaluating changes and cost/benefit. I expect we can begin that conversation next Monday/Tuesday (depending what side of the planet you're on). I'm eager to hear more perspectives and refutes in real-time, but just to be clear, Foundation has no agenda for that call other than education and creating an inclusive process across stakeholders for the betterment of the Network. (edited)
4
2
scott
Hey everyone, I reached out to several folks about this matter in the last couple of days and took in multiple perspectives. At this point, on behalf of the Helium Foundation, we'd like to halt any decision or vote that would modify the status quo of AU915 as the default LoRaWAN regional frequency for the Helium Network in Australia or New Zealand. Summarizing some of the points already made by people in this channel: a) There was limited time and discussion ahead of the straw poll b) The straw poll had relatively low participation c) Insufficient meeting notes d) Not fulfilling the nature of the HIP itself (creating the space for the public commentary period and ensuring that someone was owning the process) We will still hold the Town Hall next week as planned, however the purpose will strictly be for information sharing and discovery. The discussion will center around the technical/economic merit for each frequency relative to the region as will best optimize for Network use and roaming. We will record and publicly document the meeting to benefit future discussion if the community decides to pursue a change in the default regional frequency at a later date. Same request as before, email joey@helium.foundation if you want to participate. Now to the governance piece: Under current Helium Network governance HIP-45 is still considered approved (see Github). HIP-45 can be amended and the Foundation is happy to work with anyone on the task. If anything, I welcome it as we've been working on new structures and standards for Network governance. I want to speak to two areas of voiced concern and what we're doing about it. These are (1) HIP Approvals and (2) Committee Structure. It's currently ambiguous what gets an on-chain vote, straw poll, or can pass by rough consensus. We also need documented guidelines on vote passage, and what is decided by the whole community vs a representative group (e.g. MOC). HIP-45 put a spotlight on the ambiguity and we're doing something about it. As I recently mentioned, there's a HIP in draft that will start to standardize several areas of governance, such as various areas of decision making. It will also include a Committee framework for creating a new Committee, required documentation, voting records, and more. The Terms of Reference outlined by Leo overlaps with some of our work. We're not doing this in a vacuum, it'll be public soon. Unfortunately we've genuinely had a lot on our plate but are actively hiring in order to go faster and improve overall comms. Here's what I hope you'll take away from this: 1. That I appreciate the thoughtful, professional contributions to this discussion. The resolve of the community to ensure the Network is successful was very powerful. This is a great thing. 2. I hope everyone making strong cases in a professional manner felt heard (even if it was slower than I preferred) and that there's no unilateral effort to change anything. However we should continue to explore the options collaboratively because later change (if needed) will be more painful. 3. That there's work being done to standardize aspects of governance (voting, committee structure, and reporting) and I look forward to working with some of you on it. I'll be available for a bit here for replies but it's getting late on US east coast. (edited)
Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/05/2022 7:56 PM
Thank you Scott for listening to the concerns of the community and more importantly acting on them. As discussed yesterday we are more than willing to assist in this process and I will be presenting our governance HIP proposal at tonight's (well - VERY early morning Australia) Foundation Community Call. Thank you from down under!
7
Leo üá¶üá∫
Thank you Scott for listening to the concerns of the community and more importantly acting on them. As discussed yesterday we are more than willing to assist in this process and I will be presenting our governance HIP proposal at tonight's (well - VERY early morning Australia) Foundation Community Call. Thank you from down under!
scott 04/05/2022 7:59 PM

scott
Cheers @Leo 🇦🇺, it might make sense to fold the efforts in together. I'll DM.
Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/05/2022 8:00 PM
Agreed! Was planning to bring this up tomorrow mornings call.
Joey 04/05/2022 8:02 PM
Some of you might see some redundant emails from me with the above info. Apologies in advance, haven't got all the handles mapped to emails.
3
scott
Hey everyone, I reached out to several folks about this matter in the last couple of days and took in multiple perspectives. At this point, on behalf of the Helium Foundation, we'd like to halt any decision or vote that would modify the status quo of AU915 as the default LoRaWAN regional frequency for the Helium Network in Australia or New Zealand. Summarizing some of the points already made by people in this channel: a) There was limited time and discussion ahead of the straw poll b) The straw poll had relatively low participation c) Insufficient meeting notes d) Not fulfilling the nature of the HIP itself (creating the space for the public commentary period and ensuring that someone was owning the process) We will still hold the Town Hall next week as planned, however the purpose will strictly be for information sharing and discovery. The discussion will center around the technical/economic merit for each frequency relative to the region as will best optimize for Network use and roaming. We will record and publicly document the meeting to benefit future discussion if the community decides to pursue a change in the default regional frequency at a later date. Same request as before, email joey@helium.foundation if you want to participate. Now to the governance piece: Under current Helium Network governance HIP-45 is still considered approved (see Github). HIP-45 can be amended and the Foundation is happy to work with anyone on the task. If anything, I welcome it as we've been working on new structures and standards for Network governance. I want to speak to two areas of voiced concern and what we're doing about it. These are (1) HIP Approvals and (2) Committee Structure. It's currently ambiguous what gets an on-chain vote, straw poll, or can pass by rough consensus. We also need documented guidelines on vote passage, and what is decided by the whole community vs a representative group (e.g. MOC). HIP-45 put a spotlight on the ambiguity and we're doing something about it. As I recently mentioned, there's a HIP in draft that will start to standardize several areas of governance, such as various areas of decision making. It will also include a Committee framework for creating a new Committee, required documentation, voting records, and more. The Terms of Reference outlined by Leo overlaps with some of our work. We're not doing this in a vacuum, it'll be public soon. Unfortunately we've genuinely had a lot on our plate but are actively hiring in order to go faster and improve overall comms. Here's what I hope you'll take away from this: 1. That I appreciate the thoughtful, professional contributions to this discussion. The resolve of the community to ensure the Network is successful was very powerful. This is a great thing. 2. I hope everyone making strong cases in a professional manner felt heard (even if it was slower than I preferred) and that there's no unilateral effort to change anything. However we should continue to explore the options collaboratively because later change (if needed) will be more painful. 3. That there's work being done to standardize aspects of governance (voting, committee structure, and reporting) and I look forward to working with some of you on it. I'll be available for a bit here for replies but it's getting late on US east coast. (edited)
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 04/05/2022 8:22 PM
Thank for taking the time to get this all in writing and listening to those affected. I have one major issue however.
Under current Helium Network governance HIP-45 is still considered approved (see Github).
This HIP was never, by any realistic metric, passed by the community as HIPs are expected to be. To continue to treat this HIP as approved is antithetical to the current practices and agreed upon expectations of the community when it comes to governance. This HIP requires a full vote by the community before any rules or processes in it are used. A straw poll of ~30 people, as you yourself pointed out, is in no way sufficient consensus, specially in light of the high bar set for other HIPs in the recent past (66.6% super majority). To pick and choose what we allow the community to vote on sullies the entire process and makes a mockery of the very idea of a decentralized project. (edited)
scott
Hey everyone, I reached out to several folks about this matter in the last couple of days and took in multiple perspectives. At this point, on behalf of the Helium Foundation, we'd like to halt any decision or vote that would modify the status quo of AU915 as the default LoRaWAN regional frequency for the Helium Network in Australia or New Zealand. Summarizing some of the points already made by people in this channel: a) There was limited time and discussion ahead of the straw poll b) The straw poll had relatively low participation c) Insufficient meeting notes d) Not fulfilling the nature of the HIP itself (creating the space for the public commentary period and ensuring that someone was owning the process) We will still hold the Town Hall next week as planned, however the purpose will strictly be for information sharing and discovery. The discussion will center around the technical/economic merit for each frequency relative to the region as will best optimize for Network use and roaming. We will record and publicly document the meeting to benefit future discussion if the community decides to pursue a change in the default regional frequency at a later date. Same request as before, email joey@helium.foundation if you want to participate. Now to the governance piece: Under current Helium Network governance HIP-45 is still considered approved (see Github). HIP-45 can be amended and the Foundation is happy to work with anyone on the task. If anything, I welcome it as we've been working on new structures and standards for Network governance. I want to speak to two areas of voiced concern and what we're doing about it. These are (1) HIP Approvals and (2) Committee Structure. It's currently ambiguous what gets an on-chain vote, straw poll, or can pass by rough consensus. We also need documented guidelines on vote passage, and what is decided by the whole community vs a representative group (e.g. MOC). HIP-45 put a spotlight on the ambiguity and we're doing something about it. As I recently mentioned, there's a HIP in draft that will start to standardize several areas of governance, such as various areas of decision making. It will also include a Committee framework for creating a new Committee, required documentation, voting records, and more. The Terms of Reference outlined by Leo overlaps with some of our work. We're not doing this in a vacuum, it'll be public soon. Unfortunately we've genuinely had a lot on our plate but are actively hiring in order to go faster and improve overall comms. Here's what I hope you'll take away from this: 1. That I appreciate the thoughtful, professional contributions to this discussion. The resolve of the community to ensure the Network is successful was very powerful. This is a great thing. 2. I hope everyone making strong cases in a professional manner felt heard (even if it was slower than I preferred) and that there's no unilateral effort to change anything. However we should continue to explore the options collaboratively because later change (if needed) will be more painful. 3. That there's work being done to standardize aspects of governance (voting, committee structure, and reporting) and I look forward to working with some of you on it. I'll be available for a bit here for replies but it's getting late on US east coast. (edited)
Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/05/2022 8:35 PM
After having a chance to read everything closely I think it's important to get one thing clarified. It will be important to look at the different ways of achieving maximum potential for Helium in Australia. And that includes ways on how operators that have chosen the Asian frequency band over the Australian band could potentially make use of the Helium network. But we have to make sure the governance structure, terms of reference and conflict of interest procedures are dealt with. Either as a "fixed" HIP-45 process or under a more holistic structure for the Foundation and the committees. However, this has to be done properly and the process would need to start with a full evaluation of the options under a newly formed committee with the governance structures in place. And not where we left off - as there was never an evaluation done! The town hall exercise should be a good way to inform a committee of the issues of the people most effected by such a change and the ones who invested their time and money into building this network. Thanks again! Helium in Australia will be the stronger for it. (edited)

1
slack 04/05/2022 10:45 PM
Just want to mention to ensure we're not lost in the noise around this but NZ does still have a power restrictions between 915-920Mhz which may be a concern for deployments here. Operators here prefer AS923 for this reason and it'd be difficult for deployments to operate legally on AU915. Traditionally NZ follows AU on these sort of things since we're the little guy and it's easier to lump us together but I'm beginning to think NZ should be handled separately in this case and perhaps this is something that can be discussed on the call as well.
slack 04/05/2022 10:54 PM
Separately I was looking back at some of the issues that happened with PocV11 and the changes in the Philippines and seeing some discussion with @louis about AS923 emitting more than the 16dbm default settings (where permitted) and there being some development work required to achieve this, is this something that's progressing at all? I had a wander through the relevant code for the regional frequency stuff and couldn't see anything for per country power levels happening. It seems like this is something that may be beneficial to precede further changes to regional frequencies and if it were possible in Aus/NZ may alleviate a lot of the concerns about the power level differences.
slack
Just want to mention to ensure we're not lost in the noise around this but NZ does still have a power restrictions between 915-920Mhz which may be a concern for deployments here. Operators here prefer AS923 for this reason and it'd be difficult for deployments to operate legally on AU915. Traditionally NZ follows AU on these sort of things since we're the little guy and it's easier to lump us together but I'm beginning to think NZ should be handled separately in this case and perhaps this is something that can be discussed on the call as well.
Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/05/2022 10:55 PM
Handling Australia and NZ separately has been requested on Day 1 of the PR as they have separate regulation and issues. We still believe that any decision should be done by the respective countries.
slack 04/05/2022 10:55 PM

1
scott
Hey everyone, I reached out to several folks about this matter in the last couple of days and took in multiple perspectives. At this point, on behalf of the Helium Foundation, we'd like to halt any decision or vote that would modify the status quo of AU915 as the default LoRaWAN regional frequency for the Helium Network in Australia or New Zealand. Summarizing some of the points already made by people in this channel: a) There was limited time and discussion ahead of the straw poll b) The straw poll had relatively low participation c) Insufficient meeting notes d) Not fulfilling the nature of the HIP itself (creating the space for the public commentary period and ensuring that someone was owning the process) We will still hold the Town Hall next week as planned, however the purpose will strictly be for information sharing and discovery. The discussion will center around the technical/economic merit for each frequency relative to the region as will best optimize for Network use and roaming. We will record and publicly document the meeting to benefit future discussion if the community decides to pursue a change in the default regional frequency at a later date. Same request as before, email joey@helium.foundation if you want to participate. Now to the governance piece: Under current Helium Network governance HIP-45 is still considered approved (see Github). HIP-45 can be amended and the Foundation is happy to work with anyone on the task. If anything, I welcome it as we've been working on new structures and standards for Network governance. I want to speak to two areas of voiced concern and what we're doing about it. These are (1) HIP Approvals and (2) Committee Structure. It's currently ambiguous what gets an on-chain vote, straw poll, or can pass by rough consensus. We also need documented guidelines on vote passage, and what is decided by the whole community vs a representative group (e.g. MOC). HIP-45 put a spotlight on the ambiguity and we're doing something about it. As I recently mentioned, there's a HIP in draft that will start to standardize several areas of governance, such as various areas of decision making. It will also include a Committee framework for creating a new Committee, required documentation, voting records, and more. The Terms of Reference outlined by Leo overlaps with some of our work. We're not doing this in a vacuum, it'll be public soon. Unfortunately we've genuinely had a lot on our plate but are actively hiring in order to go faster and improve overall comms. Here's what I hope you'll take away from this: 1. That I appreciate the thoughtful, professional contributions to this discussion. The resolve of the community to ensure the Network is successful was very powerful. This is a great thing. 2. I hope everyone making strong cases in a professional manner felt heard (even if it was slower than I preferred) and that there's no unilateral effort to change anything. However we should continue to explore the options collaboratively because later change (if needed) will be more painful. 3. That there's work being done to standardize aspects of governance (voting, committee structure, and reporting) and I look forward to working with some of you on it. I'll be available for a bit here for replies but it's getting late on US east coast. (edited)
vudu 04/06/2022 12:13 AM
Hi Scott, I would like to take the time to personaly thank yourself, @louis and your team for the consideration, thoughtfulness and good judgement as applied to hip-45, AU915, AS923. Great progress. Thank you also to the vocal hordes for their persistance and Tony Smith for his excellent technical discussion. A big win for progress, unity, Helium, the network, operators, users, et al. Of course I would agree with @Leo 🇦🇺, @ElonTusk | 5Gchipped, @Jules22, @Jayce and others that it will be important to work towards a framework that supports what has been achieved to date. I would hope as a priority. The project as a whole is still in it's infancy and I'm positive we can be stronger and smarter together. And combined, the collective effort will produce better outcomes for all concerned for many future epochs.

As implied would be needed to continue the trust of the multiple subcommunities that make up Helium. With special focus on key areas ‚Äì such as perception of conflict of interest, timely documentation, decision registers, that left unchecked, can corrode the trust the Helium Foundation needs by the community to keep the network. Thank you, @scott, for stating recognition by the Helium Foundation of the professional work effort of several of us for the community (the @ would be too big here, you know who you are!) - that want it to continue as a trusted (true decentralised) wireless connectivity option worldwide.

slack 04/06/2022 6:01 PM
@louis Great doc thanks, interesting read. Not sure if you saw my question on this yesterday but you talk about the ability to configure higher power output where it's permitted but am I correct in understanding that this is something not possible with hotspots today? If not is it being worked on? It seems like it'd benefit operations in a number of other countries potentially as well (e.g. Philippines).
18:02
Also, I think there's the assumption that if higher power output were possible that this would impact PoC beacons as well, but is that definitely the case?
slack
@louis Great doc thanks, interesting read. Not sure if you saw my question on this yesterday but you talk about the ability to configure higher power output where it's permitted but am I correct in understanding that this is something not possible with hotspots today? If not is it being worked on? It seems like it'd benefit operations in a number of other countries potentially as well (e.g. Philippines).
louis 04/06/2022 6:09 PM
I did see your message and meant to respond, so thanks for reminding me. Power output is something being figured out via HIP49 https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0049-max-eirp-adjustment.md I would consider it to be a requirement before upsetting channels in AUNZ and generally something we should pursue for all regions. It all comes down to development time in the implementation.
18:10
That is to say, I think we all agree adapting power output for PoC is desirable based on local regulations, but it's a granularity of control that we don't have in code yet.
slack 04/06/2022 6:13 PM
Ah I see, hadn't seen HIP49 yet so thanks for that, makes sense to split that away from HIP45 given the complexity but they're definitely closely related.
18:14
I haven't really come across a clear explanation of how the lora standards/configs really apply to the PoC beacons and wasn't sure if it'd still be limited in this case if the default power (used for joins?) was still 16dbm
18:15
But it sounds like it's something that does need to be designed/developed to be granular enough in any case
louis
Ahead of next weeks townhall, I wanted to share my personal reasoning on how to choose channels that promote network usage in Australia and New Zealand. Happy to take feedback here, written, or during April 11 townhall. (edited)
gazmcghee 04/06/2022 6:33 PM
That looks promising. I wasn't aware of the command to change the AS downlink channels. For most of us here buying nodes, we're only interested in AU915 and from my understanding the only unusual expectation is that it uses a high set of uplink channels (34-41) and that they are across 2 incomplete banks of 8. My knowledge of nodes in practice is minimal, so I don't know if devices out there will follow the spec properly to work with this, but they should. AS923 devices will need to implement the commands new to 1.0.3 (edited)
gazmcghee 04/06/2022 6:47 PM
Does anyone have experience with nodes taking shortcuts or making bad assumptions that would cause them to fail with this channel plan? Does it contravene the spec in any way?

gazmcghee 04/06/2022 8:27 PM
@louis If the foundation could declare that it will support AU915 as a first class citizen on the AU Helium network for at least X years into the future, it would help regain a lot of the lost trust and allay fears by people buying hardware and setting up nodes in hard to access areas or in large numbers. Right now there is nothing to say there won't be another attempt to switch and leave AU915 nodes stranded. I think your proposal just above supports both AU915 and AS923 (1.0.3) as first class citizens. (edited)
4
gazmcghee
@louis If the foundation could declare that it will support AU915 as a first class citizen on the AU Helium network for at least X years into the future, it would help regain a lot of the lost trust and allay fears by people buying hardware and setting up nodes in hard to access areas or in large numbers. Right now there is nothing to say there won't be another attempt to switch and leave AU915 nodes stranded. I think your proposal just above supports both AU915 and AS923 (1.0.3) as first class citizens. (edited)
louis 04/06/2022 8:59 PM
I think it's very fair to say that the first proposals about AS923-1 did not think about how to provide ongoing support to AU915. But obviously, after the past few weeks, we must acknowledge that there's strong interest in on-going support for AU915 and that's what's inspired me to think about how to define that interoperability. There's clearly interest on both sides, so I only hope to be flexible enough to accommodate as many devices as possible. (edited)

gazmcghee 04/07/2022 12:44 AM
@louis re about your channel plan proposal. A manufacturer I just spoke to said they "haven't used channel 34-41 yet" - not sure if it will work, but they can make sure it works for future orders. Would it be possible though to use Ch 8-13 + 40 & 41 for uplinks ? That would be more typical for AU915. It seems to me that with DIChannelReq, AS923 has very few limitations on frequencies. (edited)
slack 04/07/2022 1:46 AM
@louis Can you confirm if the suggestions around band plans (where you refer to AS923-1-AU) in your doc are within the existing lorawan specs for AS923? By my reading you're not suggesting anything non-standard, and I expect that Nova wouldn't do that in any case. And if so, presumably lorawan compliant devices can be expected to work with what you're suggesting?
tonys 04/07/2022 3:51 AM
Reposted from the PR just in case this Discord is the primary communication channel. ------- Hi Louis (@louis) thanks for sharing the doc and looking forward to the discussion going forward. Could you clarify one point made by Alper in the December 2021 Technical Meeting (refer time 10:34 where he was reading notes provided to him). He said "we are able to use both Symmetric and Asymmetric channels with AS923". Was he saying that AS923 has the capability to work either as a Duplex System where the Hotspot receive and transmit frequencies are different and/or can work Simplex where they are the same? If he wasn't referring to Simplex/Duplex could you explain (or find out) what feature in the LoraWan standard he was referring to. Seems to me, this is somewhat fundamental to the discussion as it's important everyone is on the same page going forward.
1
03:54
I also posted to the PR the following ------ just to help refine your document. In the last bullet point near the bottom of page 1 you write: "The channels have a maximum offset from the center frequency by +/- 400 KHz" Remember the 400KHz limit is to the bottom or top of channel so when you reference the maximum offset to the channel's centre frequency it needs to 100KHz less. (ie half the channel bandwidth). Since the offset that's entered into the configuration files relates to the centre frequency of each channel I think for clarity your bullet point could be worded as "The centre frequency of each of the 8 channels has a maximum offset of +/- 300KHz from Radio 0 or 1's set frequency"
1
tonys
Reposted from the PR just in case this Discord is the primary communication channel. ------- Hi Louis (@louis) thanks for sharing the doc and looking forward to the discussion going forward. Could you clarify one point made by Alper in the December 2021 Technical Meeting (refer time 10:34 where he was reading notes provided to him). He said "we are able to use both Symmetric and Asymmetric channels with AS923". Was he saying that AS923 has the capability to work either as a Duplex System where the Hotspot receive and transmit frequencies are different and/or can work Simplex where they are the same? If he wasn't referring to Simplex/Duplex could you explain (or find out) what feature in the LoraWan standard he was referring to. Seems to me, this is somewhat fundamental to the discussion as it's important everyone is on the same page going forward.
gazmcghee 04/07/2022 4:12 AM
Louis's document answers that about "Asymmetric channels with AS923". The AS923 1.0.3 command DlChannelReq lets you set the downlink frequency of any channel. I wasn't aware of that - I think it changes everything. (edited)
tonys 04/07/2022 4:18 AM
@louis , can you provide a reference to the term "DlChannelReq", eg a page or line number would be handy.
1
tonys
@louis , can you provide a reference to the term "DlChannelReq", eg a page or line number would be handy.
gazmcghee 04/07/2022 4:23 AM
Its in the 1.0.3 spec document line 808. Louis is probably not up yet (edited)
tonys 04/07/2022 4:31 AM
not in the version referenced and linked in Louis' doc.

gazmcghee 04/07/2022 5:14 AM
Louis linked to the Regional Parameters (RP) document. The main doc is linked just above. As far as I know, the LoRaWAN specification consists of those 2 documents only.
gazmcghee
@louis re about your channel plan proposal. A manufacturer I just spoke to said they "haven't used channel 34-41 yet" - not sure if it will work, but they can make sure it works for future orders. Would it be possible though to use Ch 8-13 + 40 & 41 for uplinks ? That would be more typical for AU915. It seems to me that with DIChannelReq, AS923 has very few limitations on frequencies. (edited)
louis 04/07/2022 6:11 AM
It's possible to move a "set"of 4 channels around almost arbitrarily, but because of the Corecell design with the front-ends (mentioned in the hardware constraints section), you are stuck adopting at least 2 more channels "around" 40&41.
slack
@louis Can you confirm if the suggestions around band plans (where you refer to AS923-1-AU) in your doc are within the existing lorawan specs for AS923? By my reading you're not suggesting anything non-standard, and I expect that Nova wouldn't do that in any case. And if so, presumably lorawan compliant devices can be expected to work with what you're suggesting?
louis 04/07/2022 6:14 AM
To my knowledge, there is no violation of LoRaWAN spec, and, I'd say generally the spirit of the proposal is how to use what we know about the spec to maximize dual-operability. That being said, I'm passing it around quite a bit though, so maybe somebody will spot something of concern.
1
tonys
Reposted from the PR just in case this Discord is the primary communication channel. ------- Hi Louis (@louis) thanks for sharing the doc and looking forward to the discussion going forward. Could you clarify one point made by Alper in the December 2021 Technical Meeting (refer time 10:34 where he was reading notes provided to him). He said "we are able to use both Symmetric and Asymmetric channels with AS923". Was he saying that AS923 has the capability to work either as a Duplex System where the Hotspot receive and transmit frequencies are different and/or can work Simplex where they are the same? If he wasn't referring to Simplex/Duplex could you explain (or find out) what feature in the LoraWan standard he was referring to. Seems to me, this is somewhat fundamental to the discussion as it's important everyone is on the same page going forward.
louis 04/07/2022 6:15 AM
Reposting my comment from GH for visibility: Regarding, AS923-1's asymmetric capabilities, I can't speak for what Alper meant, but my understanding matches yours. I would just caveat that asymmetric channels are necessary for duplex, but does not imply it. My understanding is that actual duplex from a single gateway ends up being uncommon in practice as it requires a significant amount of filtering effort (which also makes the hardware less flexible).
tonys
@louis , can you provide a reference to the term "DlChannelReq", eg a page or line number would be handy.
louis 04/07/2022 6:17 AM
groot linked lorawan1.0.3 above. i think section 5.6 (p28) is a good explanation of how it works/what it does
tonys
not in the version referenced and linked in Louis' doc.
louis 04/07/2022 6:18 AM
i'll add the second document for future revisions of the write up. it'd be good to have references
louis
It's possible to move a "set"of 4 channels around almost arbitrarily, but because of the Corecell design with the front-ends (mentioned in the hardware constraints section), you are stuck adopting at least 2 more channels "around" 40&41.
gazmcghee 04/07/2022 6:33 AM
Ok so maybe moving a set of 4 to around channel 8 would make a difference with poorly compliant nodes. That would effectively split the plan between necessary AS923 and typical AU915 but be fully compatible with both. I would also choose channels such that the channels modulo 8 nicely aligns with 0 to 7 for AU915 downlinks. It's really hard to know what is best without testing lots of popular cheap nodes. It reminds me of stories about MS Windows having code to accommodate bugs in specific games that were very popular and considered essential in the market. (edited)
gazmcghee
Ok so maybe moving a set of 4 to around channel 8 would make a difference with poorly compliant nodes. That would effectively split the plan between necessary AS923 and typical AU915 but be fully compatible with both. I would also choose channels such that the channels modulo 8 nicely aligns with 0 to 7 for AU915 downlinks. It's really hard to know what is best without testing lots of popular cheap nodes. It reminds me of stories about MS Windows having code to accommodate bugs in specific games that were very popular and considered essential in the market. (edited)
louis 04/07/2022 6:41 AM
Yeah it's a tough problem to solve if devices are doing non-compliant things. I wonder if we can outline a few tests that could test an AU915 device and see if it would tolerate the proposed channel plan. Otherwise, we're left kind of guessing what might help them work, and possibly changing things without knowing if it helps.
06:43
My initial thought is that they simply have to tolerate LinkAdrReq setting channel masks, but I thought that command was there from the beginning so I'd be surprised if it was missing; it's hard to use a AU915/US915 node without using it...
gazmcghee 04/07/2022 6:55 AM
AU915_2 is what TTN uses too, and 95% of gateways are 8 channels, so a poorly coded node could just use 8 to 15 without problems in most cases.
tonys 04/07/2022 11:09 AM
@louis just to make sure we are using the same terminology i understand in a radio context that
11:09
Simplex is a two way communication on the same channel, one way at a time
11:10
Half Duplex is a two way communication where each way is on a different channel but only one occurs at any point in time
11:11
Full Duplex is a two way communication on different channels but both occur at the same time
tonys
@louis just to make sure we are using the same terminology i understand in a radio context that
louis 04/07/2022 11:13 AM
yep fair definitions ^
11:13
my point on GitHub is that assymetric implies either half or full duplex (afaik)
tonys 04/07/2022 11:14 AM
Agree
tonys 04/07/2022 1:34 PM
Can i therefore suggest going forward we should be clear and try and use the full terms of Half Duplex or Full Duplex. If we use the term Duplex by itself then we mean both forms, ie where the difference does not matter to the point of the discussion.
louis 04/07/2022 1:37 PM
well the terms symmetric and assymetric work, no?
13:44
i think i avoided the term duplex in the write up
13:44
oh nvm you're right
13:44
i did talk about duplex

louis

louis 04/07/2022 2:39 PM

gazmcghee 04/07/2022 2:57 PM
This is ideal and cheap for anyone else. Can also be a gateway plugged into a raspberry pi https://store.rakwireless.com/products/wisgate-developer-base?variant=39942858899654
WisGate Developer Base | RAK7271 / RAK7371
The RAK7271/RAK7371 RAK Developer Base designed for LoRa gateway solution integration with desktop/mobile/embedded systems that converts RAK2287/RAK5146 mPCIe LoRa concentrator modules into USB Type C pluggable. Ideal solution for evaluating LoRaWAN gateway deployments, due to its great portability.

Here are my links again re traffic limits : https://www.mdpi.com/1424-8220/16/9/1466/htm https://avbentem.github.io/airtime-calculator/ttn/au915/30 https://arxiv.org/pdf/1607.08011.pdf (Figure 2) https://www.bundesnetzagentur.de/SharedDocs/Downloads/DE/Sachgebiete/Telekommunikation/Unternehmen_Institutionen/Koexistenzstudie_EN.pdf;jsessionid=730E2D12E173C31C97B03AC38FE2AED4?__blob=publicationFile&v=2
A Study of LoRa: Long Range & Low Power Networks for the Internet o...
LoRa is a long-range, low-power, low-bitrate, wireless telecommunications system, promoted as an infrastructure solution for the Internet of Things: end-devices use LoRa across a single wireless hop to communicate to gateway(s), connected to the Internet and which act as transparent bridges and relay messages between these end-devices and a cent...

brett_e 04/12/2022 3:41 PM
Question at ~1:51:00 of the video Michael Vierling says "We're confident we can build a hotspot that will support AU915 and AS923 devices", this comment concerns me as we have been always told that switching to 923 that our hotspots will still work and we wouldn't need new hotspots if the frequency changed. From what Michael is saying we will all need new devices if we switch to 923, Is this correct or am I missing something.
brett_e
Question at ~1:51:00 of the video Michael Vierling says "We're confident we can build a hotspot that will support AU915 and AS923 devices", this comment concerns me as we have been always told that switching to 923 that our hotspots will still work and we wouldn't need new hotspots if the frequency changed. From what Michael is saying we will all need new devices if we switch to 923, Is this correct or am I missing something.
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 3:51 PM
His saying a duel band hotpsot. It would have to have a 16 channel Radio, As it stands out hotspots are fine. And will be fine. But in future. If we want to go down the dual frequency routes(915 and 923 from the same device), we would need a device with 2x8 channel concentrators or a 16 channel concentrator.
l34rn3d
His saying a duel band hotpsot. It would have to have a 16 channel Radio, As it stands out hotspots are fine. And will be fine. But in future. If we want to go down the dual frequency routes(915 and 923 from the same device), we would need a device with 2x8 channel concentrators or a 16 channel concentrator.
brett_e 04/12/2022 3:56 PM
So that dual channels means a new hot spot right?
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 3:56 PM
Yes. It would be a very different hotspot.
brett_e 04/12/2022 3:57 PM
Well that completely changes Louis proposal for a dual network, That definitely wasn't made clear in the meeting.
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 3:58 PM
No, his comments regarding a new Hotspot are different
15:58
On paper, Louis's plan will work with existing radios
15:59
The "new" hotpsot would be supported 16 channels at once. Under Louis's plan, we still operate on 8 channels.
brett_e 04/12/2022 3:59 PM

15:59
or would ours just work on one or the other?
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 4:01 PM
There's two different things being talked about. - A 16 channel Radio(8 extra channels to what out hardware supports, this was a "we could do this in future" option) - change the as923 frequency to line up with the current au915 frequency.
brett_e 04/12/2022 4:04 PM
ok so the "we could do this in the future" option is not what Louis is proposing with the dual channel option. Do I understand that right?
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 4:06 PM
Correct. Even then, our hardware would still work until it's end of life. It's not like we would all need to change devices overnight.
l34rn3d

If we want to go down the dual frequency routes(915 and 923 from the same device), we would need a device with 2x8 channel concentrators or a 16 channel concentrator.
mvierling 04/12/2022 4:10 PM

mvierling

l34rn3d 04/12/2022 4:12 PM
Is Louise's proposal not to use DIchanelreq?
16:12
To re arrange the 8 channels so that they match?
brett_e
Question at ~1:51:00 of the video Michael Vierling says "We're confident we can build a hotspot that will support AU915 and AS923 devices", this comment concerns me as we have been always told that switching to 923 that our hotspots will still work and we wouldn't need new hotspots if the frequency changed. From what Michael is saying we will all need new devices if we switch to 923, Is this correct or am I missing something.
mvierling 04/12/2022 4:30 PM
Please read Louis proposal again and carefully. This is a very complex technical subject and is difficult to explain to the general public. The Hotspot is configured via software and we can dynamically control every single Uplink and Downlink channel. It turns out there is some overlap between AU915 and AS923. We'll modify the Hotspot Uplink listening channels to choose a set of channels which is consistent with either AS923 or AU915 listening channel frequencies. Nobody will need to purchase a new Hotspot; they are already dual-certified for either AU915 or AS923. Once configured this way either AU915 or AS923-1 LoRa sensor devices can connect. Just to clarify. Louis and I are on the same engineering team. We collaborate and are making the same proposal. (edited)
4
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 4:31 PM
Ok, so you were also talking about Louis plan and not building a 16 channel gateway. I also understood your comment as building a dual radio hotspot. Not a reference to Louis proposal
l34rn3d
Ok, so you were also talking about Louis plan and not building a 16 channel gateway. I also understood your comment as building a dual radio hotspot. Not a reference to Louis proposal
mvierling 04/12/2022 4:33 PM
The SemTech chips used by the manufacturers do not support 16-channel gateways, so that would be impossible.
mvierling
The SemTech chips used by the manufacturers do not support 16-channel gateways, so that would be impossible.
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 4:36 PM
I thought you were talking about adding in a second chipset. So a hotspot would have 2 RF chipsets
l34rn3d
I thought you were talking about adding in a second chipset. So a hotspot would have 2 RF chipsets
mvierling 04/12/2022 4:37 PM
This is not necessary. The same 8 channels can support both AS923 and AU915 at the same time.
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 4:39 PM

ScuL 04/12/2022 4:42 PM
because the frequency channels are shifted dynamically the current 8 channels would be enough
mvierling
Please read Louis proposal again and carefully. This is a very complex technical subject and is difficult to explain to the general public. The Hotspot is configured via software and we can dynamically control every single Uplink and Downlink channel. It turns out there is some overlap between AU915 and AS923. We'll modify the Hotspot Uplink listening channels to choose a set of channels which is consistent with either AS923 or AU915 listening channel frequencies. Nobody will need to purchase a new Hotspot; they are already dual-certified for either AU915 or AS923. Once configured this way either AU915 or AS923-1 LoRa sensor devices can connect. Just to clarify. Louis and I are on the same engineering team. We collaborate and are making the same proposal. (edited)
brett_e 04/12/2022 4:42 PM
Michael, as is was a town hall meeting I would dare say it needs to be explainable to the "general public" as you call us. If its not you can't expect the general public to vote in favour of something they don't understand. We aren't all as technically savvy as some of the people putting forward the proposals so I don't think its unreasonable to be requesting the information be laid out in simple terms. but when I hear someone say "We're confident we can build a hotspot that will support AU915 and AS923 devices" to me a person of the general public it sounds like we will need new hotspots.
3
l34rn3d
Yes.. I know... But in the town hall. Your comments "build a hotpsot that supports both" suggests that a new device would be required.
mvierling 04/12/2022 4:42 PM
My presentation was limited to 20 minutes, otherwise I could have explained it in more detail. When I stated "build" I was referring to software. We have full software control of the Hotspot, including it's channels. So this is just a matter of reprogramming the Hotspots.
4
mvierling
My presentation was limited to 20 minutes, otherwise I could have explained it in more detail. When I stated "build" I was referring to software. We have full software control of the Hotspot, including it's channels. So this is just a matter of reprogramming the Hotspots.
l34rn3d 04/12/2022 4:46 PM
I agree. Less then ideal circumstances. At least we have clarification now of your statement. Thanks
3
louis 04/12/2022 6:01 PM
@tonys I just wanted to reach out and mention that I noticed that I misunderstood you yesterday when you asked about AU915 downlinks and their seperation from the uplinks. I flipped it and answered in regards to AS923-1 downlinks. To your particular question, I do think my proposed plan makes full duplex on AU915 unfeasible (although half duplex would mostly work). It is probably the biggest downside of the proposal. However, it is my opinion that it is a worthwhile sacrifice in favor of increased network usage by creating AS923-1 compatibility (one of the assumptions in my proposal). Furthermore, I think proposals like from @gazmcghee are in a direction where we can have gateways handle other frequencies that would eventually allow for some gateways to accommodate full duplex on AU915, when/where network load demands it. A key assumption of mine is that we are not at that point and that we should focus on adoption before focusing on load. Attaching the deck btw in case anyone prefer the format (edited)
Interoperability_of_AU915_and_AS923-1.pdf
480.22 KB
18:04
(also, dropping the note and leaving for the evening! have a good morning)
l34rn3d
Yes.. I know... But in the town hall. Your comments "build a hotpsot that supports both" suggests that a new device would be required.
gazmcghee 04/12/2022 6:06 PM
I had the same inkling which is why I asked @mvierling at the end if they were talking about the same thing
l34rn3d
Yes.. I know... But in the town hall. Your comments "build a hotpsot that supports both" suggests that a new device would be required.
Jaytheblader 04/12/2022 8:29 PM
The word "build" is probably a poor choice of words, the way I understand it it is "configure through firmware modifications" rather than "build"
1
Jayce 04/12/2022 8:54 PM
I agree with both @brett_e and @Jaytheblader we do need to be mindful of the audience we are presenting this information to. Without being disrespectful but if i did not have PTSD and stay awake until 4 am most days listening to videos and reading information i would not know half of what i do. with at least a quarter of the Hotspot owners in Australia you would be flat out trying to get them to change the batteries in a remote. yet lone discussing builds or firmware updates with them. Somehow we will need to relay this information in Laymans terms as not all Australians or indeed any other countryman from anywhere else in the world will understand technical discussions
brett_e
Michael, as is was a town hall meeting I would dare say it needs to be explainable to the "general public" as you call us. If its not you can't expect the general public to vote in favour of something they don't understand. We aren't all as technically savvy as some of the people putting forward the proposals so I don't think its unreasonable to be requesting the information be laid out in simple terms. but when I hear someone say "We're confident we can build a hotspot that will support AU915 and AS923 devices" to me a person of the general public it sounds like we will need new hotspots.
gazmcghee 04/12/2022 10:18 PM
It is bloody complex to understand Helium and LoRaWAN and business interests let alone invent something to combine standards in a way that can be just a software update and satisfy everyone, but that is what we've arrived at in recent weeks. There was a need for an open technical and business conversation, and hopefully it can be boiled down to a simple message before it requires any all in vote.
gazmcghee
It is bloody complex to understand Helium and LoRaWAN and business interests let alone invent something to combine standards in a way that can be just a software update and satisfy everyone, but that is what we've arrived at in recent weeks. There was a need for an open technical and business conversation, and hopefully it can be boiled down to a simple message before it requires any all in vote.
brett_e 04/12/2022 10:40 PM
@gazmcghee definitely agree, it needs to be explained simply so people understand with the pros and cons of all three options: 1) Stay on AU915 2) Switch to AS923 3) Run Dual frequencies (which sounds like it is the preferred way moving forward) The way I see it is we have a system that works on AU915 and that currently has devices on it that are working. Why would I want to vote for a change that can‚Äôt really be explained except as "it will be better, trust us, there will be more people using it if we switch". For full disclosure, I have no affiliation with any of the organisations/persons that are either pro the switch to AS923 or in favor of staying on AU915. I'm just a bloke with a miner that wants what's best for "The People's Network"
3
2

And your option 2 I believe is no longer on the table. It has been replaced by the Dual The issue will be to get some details on the AU915 support of the "dual frequency" plan. Since this currently is a theoretic exercise as nobody knows if AU915 devices will work and continue to work. We also have not heard from LoRa Alliance if this is going to be within the regional parameters and their guidance. Once that is all known and the HIP-45 process and the committee governance & TOC are established this can be done properly and the information out there so it can be evaluated.

gazmcghee 04/12/2022 11:42 PM

1
Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/12/2022 11:58 PM
One thing that got completely lost yesterday is that this whole frequency debate is really just a distraction. The real problem is the incentive structure. The stakeholders in this currently are 1) Helium Foundation 2) Nova Inc 3) 720K+ gateway operators (collectively invested close to a billion AUD in hardware and time) 4) External roaming partners Right now the only winners from this debate in AU are: - Nova Inc (custom LNS fees and otherwise no transparency) - External roaming partners (usage of greatest LoRa network in history for peanuts at no CAPEX)
00:01
The REAL question should be is the current DC burn model sufficient to incentivise gateway operators into the future. Not what frequency are we using. Helium is growing rapidly on the current frequency. The network works and is 100% fit for purpose. A frequency change would have AT BEST some marginal short term improvement with long-term capacity downsides. In reality it will probably be the same for either model. As customers don't care about the frequency. That is why Tony and I were focusing on the commercial benefits and roaming models yesterday (unfortunately the slides were re-made up on the fly thanks to Google). All the current devices external partners got deployed now are meaningless (on top of the numbers not even known) as no DC will be burned for packets they receive from their own network.
mvierling 04/13/2022 12:01 AM
There is no mystery. Lets say Helium and NNNCo established a LoRaWAN roaming agreement tomorrow. Sensor companies would contract with NNNCo's network to handle their sensor data. However if the sensor "roams" and connects to the Helium network, Helium will forward that traffic directly to NNNCo via a Roaming Hub. Helium's Roaming software has been a significant engineering effort. NNNCo will pay for that traffic and 100% of the data's DC price will instantly get transferred to your Miner's Wallet. So will Helium Miners benefit from roaming? Miners will greatly benefit, since Miner earnings will be primarily dependent on data traffic. Likewise if NNNCo gets sensor traffic destined for the Helium network, Helium will pay for that traffic. The money will come directly from the sensor device's Wallet, the same as it does today. The only way these network Roaming agreements will become reality is if the Helium network supports AS923. All commerical LoRaWAN operators in Australia, New Zealand and all of Asia exclusively use AS923 per guidance from the LoRa Alliance. (edited)
mvierling
There is no mystery. Lets say Helium and NNNCo established a LoRaWAN roaming agreement tomorrow. Sensor companies would contract with NNNCo's network to handle their sensor data. However if the sensor "roams" and connects to the Helium network, Helium will forward that traffic directly to NNNCo via a Roaming Hub. Helium's Roaming software has been a significant engineering effort. NNNCo will pay for that traffic and 100% of the data's DC price will instantly get transferred to your Miner's Wallet. So will Helium Miners benefit from roaming? Miners will greatly benefit, since Miner earnings will be primarily dependent on data traffic. Likewise if NNNCo gets sensor traffic destined for the Helium network, Helium will pay for that traffic. The money will come directly from the sensor device's Wallet, the same as it does today. The only way these network Roaming agreements will become reality is if the Helium network supports AS923. All commerical LoRaWAN operators in Australia, New Zealand and all of Asia exclusively use AS923 per guidance from the LoRa Alliance. (edited)

Australia and New Zealand Switching to AS923-1 by lthiery · Pull Re...
On December 10th, 2021, during the third meeting of DeWi‚Äôs LoRaWAN Working Group, members voted to initiate a change of frequency plan for Australia and New Zealand from AU915 to AS923-1. The vote ...

mvierling 04/13/2022 12:17 AM
I've personally talked with 10+ sources. They all consistently say the same thing. Some will only say it privately. But I've also shown that data usage evidence also back this up. Australia is not processing the amount of data it should be processing proportional to its population and GDP. I've recently gathered a lot more Helium usage data. I'll should be able to process share some of that data in a couple days. The Helium APIs are open, so in theory anybody on this Channel can gather the data and do their own analysis. But my initial analysis shows that Australia is very much under-performing compared to other countries. I just picked France randomly. (edited)

If your going to cherry pick a location to compare with to support the usage argument then why not try somewhere like Texas which has a land size similar to France but a population similar to Australia. i'd be interested to see those graphs.

mvierling 04/13/2022 12:42 AM
Fair point, and I'm not a market analyst. I've gathered the data best I could. Longer term this kind of market analysis belongs to the Marketing department. Primarily I spoke to a diverse set of people, with different backgrounds. What I observed is that everyone consistently gave me the same information. The evidence I gathered was consistent with the folks I spoke with. If you listen to some of the other presenters, it makes a lot of sense why the AU915 traffic is low because AU915 sensor devices are just not very widely deployed or available in the global supply chain.

louis 04/13/2022 1:26 AM
You guys can go in circles on AS923-1 or AU915 being better, but the fact is, there is not a load problem in Australia. Therefore, a plan that focuses on AU915 at the expense of AS923-1 is not justified. A dual plan solution gives AS923-1 access to the network and only loses out of spec AU915 devices. It‚Äôs no stretch of the imagination to believe that‚Äôs a net positive for usage. (edited)
slack 04/13/2022 1:28 AM
Probably many devices that don't work, or aren't optimal, with the dual plan solution can be reconfigured to as923 with some manual intervention too

Jaytheblader 04/13/2022 1:37 AM
I was petitioning to get the Helium network running in Australia late 2021 as i had a potential contract for 1000 + nodes @ 300 messages each per day that the TTN network was not going to cut it for due to coverage issues and by the time the network was sufficient in Adelaide i had lost the opportunity. So a lot of the reason we don't yet have traffic is not due to the channel plan we are on it is due to not having enough gateways for long enough, please don't compare apples to oranges. That being said i am all for a dual channel plan gateway if we can get it working and also am willing to offer my time to help test.

John
Helium hotspot growth in Australia - Sept Update - Helium ACT
A short post today. As of 14 September 2021, there are 179 Helium hotspots in Australia and they‚Äôve earned a little over 1,030 HNT combined. Here‚Äôs a distribution of Helium hotspot growth since the first hotspots came online in October 2020. August was significant, and September is lagging a little, although many anticipate taking delivery [‚Ä¶]

However if the sensor "roams" and connects to the Helium network, Helium will forward that traffic directly to NNNCo via a Roaming Hub. Helium's Roaming software has been a significant engineering effort. NNNCo will pay for that traffic and 100% of the data's DC price will instantly get transferred to your Miner's Wallet. So will Helium Miners benefit from roaming? Miners will greatly benefit, since Miner earnings will be primarily dependent on data traffic. Jayce 04/13/2022 1:42 AM
Mike its Jayson here can i ask why would Helium set up an Alliance with NNNCO when they have no respect for the network and have no units on the network as admitted yesterday and mentioned nothing but "WHAT I NEED" basically claiming they need to get helium to change for their purposes, why would helium consider this and cut out the guys already using the AU915 network
mvierling 04/13/2022 1:43 AM
A few naysayers seem to be missing the spirit of Helium's proposal presented at the recent Town hall. Originally Helium did propose a plan switch based on expert committee guidance we received. The guidance was poorly communicated and lacked community outreach. The feedback was vocal and rightfully so. But the guidance was not wrong. Further we anticipate large roaming opportunities which benefit everyone, including Miners. Helium listened and is now proposing a dual-plan software upgrade. With this software upgrade, your existing Hotspot will support traffic from both AU915 and AS923 devcies. This seems like an obvious win-win for everyone. Helium already rolls out new software upgrades to the Hotspot Miners every two weeks. If the community supports this concept we'll begin the software engineering work shortly. It will not be deployed without thorough QA and Stage testing to make sure it works perfectly. The worst that could happen is this idea won't work and will get rolled back. However Helium Engineering has vetted the concept with LoRa experts and so far everyone agrees it will work. I collaborate with a team of experienced, talented, innovative and highly motivated engineers. Prior to LoRa our engineers literally invented their own IoT protocol, so this type of engineering is, to be honest, not difficult for us. Is anyone opposed to doubling or tripling the size of the Helium network in Australia? Does the Australian Helium community really want to lose out on the opportunity to add additional AS923 traffic while continuing to support AU915 traffic?
1
mvierling
A few naysayers seem to be missing the spirit of Helium's proposal presented at the recent Town hall. Originally Helium did propose a plan switch based on expert committee guidance we received. The guidance was poorly communicated and lacked community outreach. The feedback was vocal and rightfully so. But the guidance was not wrong. Further we anticipate large roaming opportunities which benefit everyone, including Miners. Helium listened and is now proposing a dual-plan software upgrade. With this software upgrade, your existing Hotspot will support traffic from both AU915 and AS923 devcies. This seems like an obvious win-win for everyone. Helium already rolls out new software upgrades to the Hotspot Miners every two weeks. If the community supports this concept we'll begin the software engineering work shortly. It will not be deployed without thorough QA and Stage testing to make sure it works perfectly. The worst that could happen is this idea won't work and will get rolled back. However Helium Engineering has vetted the concept with LoRa experts and so far everyone agrees it will work. I collaborate with a team of experienced, talented, innovative and highly motivated engineers. Prior to LoRa our engineers literally invented their own IoT protocol, so this type of engineering is, to be honest, not difficult for us. Is anyone opposed to doubling or tripling the size of the Helium network in Australia? Does the Australian Helium community really want to lose out on the opportunity to add additional AS923 traffic while continuing to support AU915 traffic?

mvierling
A few naysayers seem to be missing the spirit of Helium's proposal presented at the recent Town hall. Originally Helium did propose a plan switch based on expert committee guidance we received. The guidance was poorly communicated and lacked community outreach. The feedback was vocal and rightfully so. But the guidance was not wrong. Further we anticipate large roaming opportunities which benefit everyone, including Miners. Helium listened and is now proposing a dual-plan software upgrade. With this software upgrade, your existing Hotspot will support traffic from both AU915 and AS923 devcies. This seems like an obvious win-win for everyone. Helium already rolls out new software upgrades to the Hotspot Miners every two weeks. If the community supports this concept we'll begin the software engineering work shortly. It will not be deployed without thorough QA and Stage testing to make sure it works perfectly. The worst that could happen is this idea won't work and will get rolled back. However Helium Engineering has vetted the concept with LoRa experts and so far everyone agrees it will work. I collaborate with a team of experienced, talented, innovative and highly motivated engineers. Prior to LoRa our engineers literally invented their own IoT protocol, so this type of engineering is, to be honest, not difficult for us. Is anyone opposed to doubling or tripling the size of the Helium network in Australia? Does the Australian Helium community really want to lose out on the opportunity to add additional AS923 traffic while continuing to support AU915 traffic?
Jaytheblader 04/13/2022 1:54 AM
I definitely do not wish to argue against the merits of having both AS923 and AU915 on the same gateway I'm all for this but I will say that the method for assessing that there is more traffic on AS923 than AU915 and hence a bigger future traffic potential is flawed. My experience on the ground in Australia shows that AU915 is very busy.
2

2
louis
@tonys I just wanted to reach out and mention that I noticed that I misunderstood you yesterday when you asked about AU915 downlinks and their seperation from the uplinks. I flipped it and answered in regards to AS923-1 downlinks. To your particular question, I do think my proposed plan makes full duplex on AU915 unfeasible (although half duplex would mostly work). It is probably the biggest downside of the proposal. However, it is my opinion that it is a worthwhile sacrifice in favor of increased network usage by creating AS923-1 compatibility (one of the assumptions in my proposal). Furthermore, I think proposals like from @gazmcghee are in a direction where we can have gateways handle other frequencies that would eventually allow for some gateways to accommodate full duplex on AU915, when/where network load demands it. A key assumption of mine is that we are not at that point and that we should focus on adoption before focusing on load. Attaching the deck btw in case anyone prefer the format (edited)
sloany 04/13/2022 4:22 AM
If the hybrid proposal is to be considered, I think it will be important to measure what sort of impact in losing full duplex on AU915 has, even if minor to put concerns at ease. Eg how many sensors/bandwidth can be supported on half duplex compared to full duplex, and if half duplex will still be enought to support projected network growth long term.
1
1
1
sloany
If the hybrid proposal is to be considered, I think it will be important to measure what sort of impact in losing full duplex on AU915 has, even if minor to put concerns at ease. Eg how many sensors/bandwidth can be supported on half duplex compared to full duplex, and if half duplex will still be enought to support projected network growth long term.
louis 04/13/2022 5:39 AM
I'd love to have that analysis done, but doing it well via simulation is a monstrous amount of work. It's almost as hard as implementing the system itself. There might be ways to use the existing studies to make some helpful inferences, but even that is a good bit of research. The proposal I wrote frames things very specifically: we don't have a load problem today, we have an access problem. Why deny AS923-1 devices access to the Helium Network today for the sake of AU915 scalability tomorrow? Even then, if we have load problems tomorrow, we have a lot of options at our finger tips. We can change channel plan again. We can deploy more gateways and organize their spectrum coverage to gain more bandwidth. We can implement better ADR.
2
louis
I'd love to have that analysis done, but doing it well via simulation is a monstrous amount of work. It's almost as hard as implementing the system itself. There might be ways to use the existing studies to make some helpful inferences, but even that is a good bit of research.
