gazmcghee 04/13/2022 5:55 AM
@mvierling I wrote this in my email to Joey for the Town Hall. It gives some context to the Australian Helium experience to date. This is all about hotspots, not nodes. Australia has had a rough time with Helium, more than other countries. 1) Public LoRaWAN in Australia goes back to the beginning of TTN, around 2016. The free use tier was embraced by over 40 IoT user groups around Australia running over 500 gateways - the largest public network in the country. And in 2021, after a significant debate came to agreement on AU915 as its main frequency band. 2) There was no manufacturer taking orders for Australia until February 2021, when Nebra made promises and took orders and payments that were delivered 4-6 months later. 3) The first hotspot to be delivered to Australia only had 2 months of earning before the August halving. It arrived at the end of May when there were 45,000 globally. 4) In early September, there were still only 150 hotspots in the country vs 150,000 globally. 5) There were no other manufacturers taking orders from Australia until Sensecap did in August. 6) There were promises and major delays and problems with Calchip, Linxdot and Syncrobit. Others have been very slow to or still have not supported AU915 even though it would only take software configuration and regulatory approval to do so. 7) So Australia was excluded from the huge HNT earnings that early US hosts enjoyed. 8) We lost thousands of dollars due to the difference between promises and when they delivered. Things only got better when IoTStore became Sensecap distributor around September. 8) After finally getting going, we've now had the frequency change issue raised 3 times This is why the tone of the Australian Helium community may have sounded irritated from the start of this process. (edited)
6
Jayce 04/13/2022 5:58 AM
@gazmcghee and not to forget a lot of people ordered many 100s of units and indeed half are still waiting now with outlays of between 140k to 190k depends who you speak with. of as they see it now dead money because many of the manufactures will now no longer give refunds
gazmcghee 04/13/2022 5:59 AM
@mvierling I don't actually want to rehash these things - I just don't think the US Helium staff & community understand the context here.

So I doubt their claim on that page "We have deployed LoRaWAN networks in every capital city"
LoRaWAN Coverage - NNNCo.
NNNCo is rolling out a national, secure Low Power Wide Area IoT network and platform to enable multiple industries and has deployed LoRaWAN networks in every capital city and many regions
06:15
@mvierling Regarding the node market, please have a look at https://www.iot-store.com.au/collections/lorawan which we all refer to for nodes. You'll see nearly all nodes there support AU915. Delivery times might not be what you're used to in the US, but supply chains have been stretched across the board. My experience with LoRaWAN only goes back a couple of years, but I've been pretty obsessed with it and haven't heard from professionals (here or WA's leading consultant) any show stopping supply problem getting AU915 nodes. Someone prove me wrong. (edited)
LoRa/LoRaWAN IoT Solutions @ IoT Store Australia
LoRa/LoRaWAN IoT Solutions available at IOT Store Australia which is the #1 Online Distributor for Plug and Play Internet of Things Solutions, IOT Boards and Dev Kit, Comms, IOT Sensor, Node/Gateway, Modem & Router, Automation Tools, Smart Devices, Open Source Dev Boards & Robotics Hardware

Jayce 04/13/2022 7:36 AM

07:39
that above is not taking in towns such as Mackay or townsville or other towns in NSW i have started to set up networks so its pretty clear Helium Does not need NNNCO its the other way around i guess thats why Tony kept saying what i need and what i want during his discussions. but lets over look that right
mvierling
There is no mystery. Lets say Helium and NNNCo established a LoRaWAN roaming agreement tomorrow. Sensor companies would contract with NNNCo's network to handle their sensor data. However if the sensor "roams" and connects to the Helium network, Helium will forward that traffic directly to NNNCo via a Roaming Hub. Helium's Roaming software has been a significant engineering effort. NNNCo will pay for that traffic and 100% of the data's DC price will instantly get transferred to your Miner's Wallet. So will Helium Miners benefit from roaming? Miners will greatly benefit, since Miner earnings will be primarily dependent on data traffic. Likewise if NNNCo gets sensor traffic destined for the Helium network, Helium will pay for that traffic. The money will come directly from the sensor device's Wallet, the same as it does today. The only way these network Roaming agreements will become reality is if the Helium network supports AS923. All commerical LoRaWAN operators in Australia, New Zealand and all of Asia exclusively use AS923 per guidance from the LoRa Alliance. (edited)
gazmcghee 04/13/2022 7:40 AM
So the DC charge (whether roaming or not) goes 100% to hotspot hosts. Therefore Nova must have confidential revenue from contracts with roaming partners for that traffic, which they are entitled to of course.
07:45
The roaming deals are essential to validate the Helium business model, and fund Nova Labs and therefore support the HNT price for PoC. So we're doing this roaming for the viability of the whole project, not because we are suddenly going to earn a lot more due to NNNCo nodes passing by our hotspots.
gazmcghee 04/13/2022 8:07 AM
By my calculations, a data-only hotspot running 8 channels at 18% (maximum ALOHA throughput) on SF7 earns 60c per hour or $5256 per year in DC. Thats absolute max best case, but more than I thought it would be. People who arrange a group of hotspots in a remote field optimising for PoC will get nothing in DC. SF8 approximately halves that. (edited)
gazmcghee
The roaming deals are essential to validate the Helium business model, and fund Nova Labs and therefore support the HNT price for PoC. So we're doing this roaming for the viability of the whole project, not because we are suddenly going to earn a lot more due to NNNCo nodes passing by our hotspots.
louis 04/13/2022 8:10 AM
I think it's important to realize that Nova is not intended to have some special status on the network. As you probably heard recently, anyone can buy an OUI and run a Console to buy packets from the Helium Network. For roaming, we're using a kludgey tool to make it work in the short-term which does have us in the middle, but HIP46 makes roaming equal access to anyone. It only requires a verified LoRaWAN Alliance NetID. So we do intend on offering value-add services like console and roaming and potentially creating some margin based on the base-price of buying traffic from hotspots, but blockchain's architecture is such that anyone can compete or bypass Nova. https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0046-lorawan-netid-routing.md (edited)
Jayce 04/13/2022 8:33 AM
But as i said previously and will say again and even said at town hall if the two can work side by side without an issue i welcome that and look forward to it.
1
gazmcghee
The roaming deals are essential to validate the Helium business model, and fund Nova Labs and therefore support the HNT price for PoC. So we're doing this roaming for the viability of the whole project, not because we are suddenly going to earn a lot more due to NNNCo nodes passing by our hotspots.
Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/13/2022 3:09 PM

The only thing we are talking about in Australia is that they have chosen the wrong frequency plan. We have also established that the currently installed base is meaningless as it corresponds with their current network footprint. So it will contribute exactly bugger all to DC growth right now. Only "future" growth outside their footprint would do that. And we have no numbers on this - just wild speculation.

15:11

There is more coming out of the woodwork every day. The HIP-45 process is being fixed and the committee structure. This is a very disruptive and high-risk change. Everyone is clear on the process. Now just see if it actually works and get some guidance from LoRa Alliance. And also get some facts on the table rather than "I have spoken to a few people and they agree with me".

The proposal I wrote frames things very specifically: we don't have a load problem today, we have an access problem. Roaming relies on HIP46, which was only approved on Feb 8th. Is it fully operating with Actility globally yet? If it is, there should be an uptick in the DC global burn on the date it was switched on. (edited)
18:40
@Leo 🇦🇺
We have also established that the currently installed base is meaningless as it corresponds with their current network footprint. So it will contribute exactly bugger all to DC growth right now.
I get the argument re stationary nodes, although helium hotspots in range might be affected. The catch could be that NNNCo won't "buy" packets that they already got through their own gateways. But for NNNCo travelling nodes eg. transport tracking this means eg. transport nodes will suddenly have national coverage, and our hotpots could see packets from trucks that were always passing by but being ignored. We could also see packets from international travelling nodes. At the very least it opens new business opportunities for NNNCo, although Helium-direct suppliers will be competing with them there. I did think we would get some estimate of benefit to hosts in the Town Hall. (edited)

adam jamal

Fizzy 04/15/2022 9:30 AM
Right, PoC11 among other things made sure regulations were being followed at a country level. Just becuase they do not prohibit lora on EU868 does not mean it is allowed. No law, rules, or regulations just means some gov official can suddenly make one. And if a law was made against, I doubt anyone on the dev team or foundation would hear about it. It would be the end-users that would be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. (edited)
09:32
And we wouldn't want you fined or jailed because you put up an antenna in a country that just didn't have any law at the time of when you set it up.
adam jamal
I was told to ask her
louis 04/15/2022 9:33 AM
I know the LoRaWAN Committee and @mvierling are working on providing guidelines for these situations. My understanding so far is that the fastest way at the moment is to try to work with the LoRaWAN Alliance to get them to provide the guidance. Often they need someone local to work with the local government to get them to draft regulations that the alliance can then use to make a recommendation. With LoRaWAN Alliance guidance, the Helium Network can follow. (edited)
3
louis
I know the LoRaWAN Committee and @mvierling are working on providing guidelines for these situations. My understanding so far is that the fastest way at the moment is to try to work with the LoRaWAN Alliance to get them to provide the guidance. Often they need someone local to work with the local government to get them to draft regulations that the alliance can then use to make a recommendation. With LoRaWAN Alliance guidance, the Helium Network can follow. (edited)
Jayce 04/16/2022 4:10 AM

sloany
Looks like there's quite a few jurisdictions without a frequency plan defined/legislated.
Jaytheblader 04/16/2022 4:27 PM
Many of them are also the sort of places that are likely to bring in snap legislation outlawing the use of LoRa so it is very important to have this HIP and its proposed amendments build a strong system to tackle the issues that will be arising as we move forward. Some pain in getting things right now will save a lot of pain later on.
l34rn3d 04/18/2022 4:30 PM
I have a spare sensecap Hotspot I was planning on running my own firmware with. I can provide remote access to this device and some nodes if that would help
tonys 04/19/2022 3:34 AM
I've seen a lot of discussion regarding simulations and tests but we before we get into all of this we should start by looking at something more fundamental. From a Sustainable Business point of view one of the fundamental questions is how many channels are needed to transport the required traffic levels. To explain this further. Every business has a "Break Even Point", ie the point where the Revenue exceeds the Costs. Below this the business is not sustainable and is simply burning cash provided by its investors. Above this, the business has the chance to survive and grow. For a business like Helium which is transporting data packets, revenue is simply the product of the Cost per Packet by the Number of Packets. Since Helium promotes a very low cost per packet it implies it will require a higher number of packets per day to reach the Break Even point. So instead of guessing if we need 8, 16 or more channels we can simply calculate the minimum number of channels for the business to be sustainable. So lets undertake some simple Traffic Engineering rather than assuming "She'll be Right". Now, I'm sure Helium would have already performed something like this as I'm sure this would be presented to investors in one form or another.
03:34
Now, once we have an idea of the minimum number of required channels we can use this to evaluate the options of AS923 and AU915. By this I mean we can determine if the 16 channels of AS923 are sufficient or whether the additional channels available in AU915 are required for the business to survive. Background information for those playing along at home: - AU915 works in 8 blocks of 8 channles and already provides the capability to expand to a total of 64 channels - AS923 has an initial 7 channels and with additional commands has the ability to expand to a total of 16 channels. Outside of that would require either a modification to the Standard or a non-standard node. So let's have a look at how to apply Traffic Engineering to this. In the case of LoraWan, when we look at this its actually rather simple as there is no real time Control Channel informing each node of which channels are in use and which ones are free. In a mobile phone network the handset makes an informed decisions of which channel to make a connection whereas LoraWan the node will simply sends a packets on the channel set by the frequency hopping plan. While I can calculate the minimum number of channels for a sustainable business I won't go any deeper into this here, suffice to say the calculation is very simple. All we need is the number of packets per hour, the average length of a packet and an agreement on the number of packets (eg 2%) that will fail to reach the destination due to congestion. We can also account for the more modern SX1302/3 base band receivers having 16 decoders which allows two or more nodes to transmit on the same frequency provided their modulations are orthogonal. (edited)
03:35
@scott and @louis this is an example from my Town Hall presentation where a Commercially focused committee would seek advice from a range of groups. Here it would be related to Traffic Engineering which may not be the expertise of people from the Lora Alliance committees. I'm more than happy to explain this in more detail, if you wish to explore this further. (edited)
2
2
gazmcghee 04/19/2022 4:57 AM
@Tony Spencer while you can do calculations based on DCs, consider that Nova can charge roaming partners whatever they like in addition to DCs, and hosts will only get paid for the DCs.
gazmcghee
@Tony Spencer while you can do calculations based on DCs, consider that Nova can charge roaming partners whatever they like in addition to DCs, and hosts will only get paid for the DCs.
tonys 04/19/2022 5:05 AM
While you might say, Nova may like to charge "what ever they like" this isn't necessarily sustainable. Many inter-carrier agreements around the world have not survived for long. Others based on keeping 100% of revenue have not even seen the light of day as the financiers would not proceed on that basis as they knew it was too risky. Examples of this span Postal, Telecoms and even the case a few years ago involving Netflix. (edited)
1

I've seen a lot of discussion regarding simulations and tests but we before we get into all of this we should start by looking at something more fundamental. From a Sustainable Business point of view one of the fundamental questions is how many channels are needed to transport the required traffic levels. To explain this further. Every business has a "Break Even Point", ie the point where the Revenue exceeds the Costs. Below this the business is not sustainable and is simply burning cash provided by its investors. Above this, the business has the chance to survive and grow. For a business like Helium which is transporting data packets, revenue is simply the product of the Cost per Packet by the Number of Packets. Since Helium promotes a very low cost per packet it implies it will require a higher number of packets per day to reach the Break Even point. So instead of guessing if we need 8, 16 or more channels we can simply calculate the minimum number of channels for the business to be sustainable. Now, I'm sure Helium would have already performed something like this as I'm sure this would be presented to investors in one form or another.
mvierling 04/19/2022 8:01 AM
From the upcoming Regional 2022 spec (section 2.14.2):
AS923 end-devices SHALL feature a channel data structure to store the parameters of at least 24 channels. A channel data structure corresponds to a frequency and a set of data rates usable on this frequency
AS923 supports a minimum of 24 channels and a maximum of 80 channels. (edited)
mvierling
From the upcoming Regional 2022 spec (section 2.14.2):
AS923 end-devices SHALL feature a channel data structure to store the parameters of at least 24 channels. A channel data structure corresponds to a frequency and a set of data rates usable on this frequency
AS923 supports a minimum of 24 channels and a maximum of 80 channels. (edited)
gazmcghee 04/19/2022 8:52 AM
What spec and line is that? RP 1.0.3 says at least 16 (line 1369) and max 16 (line 1433) (edited)
mvierling
From the upcoming Regional 2022 spec (section 2.14.2):
AS923 end-devices SHALL feature a channel data structure to store the parameters of at least 24 channels. A channel data structure corresponds to a frequency and a set of data rates usable on this frequency
AS923 supports a minimum of 24 channels and a maximum of 80 channels. (edited)

I've seen a lot of discussion regarding simulations and tests but we before we get into all of this we should start by looking at something more fundamental. From a Sustainable Business point of view one of the fundamental questions is how many channels are needed to transport the required traffic levels. To explain this further. Every business has a "Break Even Point", ie the point where the Revenue exceeds the Costs. Below this the business is not sustainable and is simply burning cash provided by its investors. Above this, the business has the chance to survive and grow. For a business like Helium which is transporting data packets, revenue is simply the product of the Cost per Packet by the Number of Packets. Since Helium promotes a very low cost per packet it implies it will require a higher number of packets per day to reach the Break Even point. So instead of guessing if we need 8, 16 or more channels we can simply calculate the minimum number of channels for the business to be sustainable. louis 04/19/2022 9:55 AM
My initial point remains that simulations are "extra work", as is the notion of focusing on break-even business units to make this decision. My proposal focuses on some very basic facts which allows us to shortcut a lot of conversation and focus on what matters: * load is not an issue today and can be handled in many ways in the future (same with business sustainability) * today, we want to do everything to promote usage. => therefore a plan that provides compatibility is desirable for the network. Others are free to undertake simulations or business analysis, but this is enough for me to be convinced that the dual plan solution is best for the network. There is no reason to have a channel plan that excludes AS923-1 devices from the network. (edited)

18:57
Honestly, and this is probably going to be unpopular, but this kind of discussion (not just today) makes a case for HIP45 being too open to community input, and even makes me wonder if community voting is appropriate. Because so far really the only input from the community that has been helpful and valid is the original concern raised about the power levels, simplex/duplex and the backwards compatibility, which Nova are now in the process of mitigating, and it was right to stop/delay the change because of this.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 04/19/2022 6:57 PM
Just watch out for Wik
slack 04/19/2022 6:57 PM
Otherwise, there‚Äôs just been constant misunderstandings and misinterpretation of the proposals, the Lora standards, the roles and responsibilities of the various parties, and it all just creates noise around the core issues. At the end of the day Nova and the Helium Foundation are the groups responsible and accountable for the development (commercially and technically) of the network we all operate. Our role as a community of operators is to hold them to task and call out when things could be improved, but not to the extent where we‚Äôre riding their back and telling them how to do their jobs.
18:58
I believe we do need to trust and expect that they do have the best interests of the Helium network in mind, including the best HNT returns to hotspot operators because it‚Äôs critical to the sustainability of the network, as well as their business, in the long term. The emotional argumentative rhetoric will just push them away from engaging with the community and that really helps nobody.
18:58
As far as HIP45 goes, LoraWAN Technical Committee are still best placed to make the assessment on whether a change is required and warranted, and to explain the reasoning for this. But I suspect that the community, particularly in this case, may be incapable of reaching consensus so perhaps there should be a different process to determine whether any concerns raised are valid and significant, and then whether they‚Äôre mitigated or resolved in subsequent revisions the proposal.
slack

But I suspect that the community, particularly in this case, may be incapable of reaching consensus so perhaps there should be a different process to determine whether any concerns raised are valid and significant, and then whether they‚Äôre mitigated or resolved in subsequent revisions the proposal.

I do also believe that there is a lot of design, coding and testing of dual channel gateways that can be done in the meantime to prove the concept will work as expected so that when the reformed LoRaWAN technical committee is ready we can hit the ground running.

gazmcghee 04/19/2022 11:19 PM
@louis I think it is fair to expect Nova or HF to provide engineering resources to enable the community to test their devices and report back for analysis by all. I'm thinking of a Docker container that can be set up with a USB concentrator. There may or may not be a hosted server for it. Nova and HF will gain from onboarding roaming partners, and so they should be able to put some of their funding into making it as easy as possible. This will expose devices that perhaps don't work on Helium on any frequency band including AU and AS. Manufacturers will then know to fix issues and do a firmware update. The marketplace will also then have greater confidence when buying devices on the list and confidence in the network in general. HF could also sell some badge to say the device has been tested and known to work on Helium. (edited)
gazmcghee

I'm thinking of a Docker container that can be set up with a USB concentrator. There may or may not be a hosted server for it. Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/20/2022 12:56 AM
What gives you that idea? I thought this is all about network growth? And that is one thing we can 100% support. But we want to make sure we are doing it right. And sticking with the process that we had to fix along the way. We are experiencing rapid growth in Australia. All we are asking is some due diligence and sticking to the process rather than rushing to "shortcuts". This is just basic change management procedure. None of these questions should be anything new for a large worldwide network of 750K gateways. You want large enterprises to use this network? You want to cope with growth? You better have answers to these questions.

Leo üá¶üá∫ 04/20/2022 1:06 AM
There is a LOT of ways of encouraging network uptake. Last time I checked making a massive unproven change without any due diligence and proper process wasn't one on the list of recommended approaches. Can you tell me how many transactions need to go over the network for gateway owners to make a reasonable return from data credits in a world of diminishing PoC returns? Can your solution support this network that is needed for the DC economics to stack up? And we are not talking about a long time in the future. We are talking very soon. These are the ACTUAL questions that will need to be answered for this network to succeed and scale. And that is the question Tony is asking on behalf of people concerned about their earnings. We KNOW that the current network is capable of scaling to this. But we don't even know the proposed solution even works in real life yet. Everybody is willing to consider a BETTER solution. But at this stage we don't even know if it will work. And we have ZERO evidence that it will actually increase uptake. Once we have the facts and test results and then we can go through the process agreed at the town hall. Not "assumption" and ooopsy "the worst thing that can happen is we can just roll back"
01:09
We have always said that we will assist with testing and go through the fixed HIP-45 process if the solution stacks up.
gazmcghee
@louis I think it is fair to expect Nova or HF to provide engineering resources to enable the community to test their devices and report back for analysis by all. I'm thinking of a Docker container that can be set up with a USB concentrator. There may or may not be a hosted server for it. Nova and HF will gain from onboarding roaming partners, and so they should be able to put some of their funding into making it as easy as possible. This will expose devices that perhaps don't work on Helium on any frequency band including AU and AS. Manufacturers will then know to fix issues and do a firmware update. The marketplace will also then have greater confidence when buying devices on the list and confidence in the network in general. HF could also sell some badge to say the device has been tested and known to work on Helium. (edited)

slack 04/20/2022 2:20 AM
I take your point here, there's probably a balance to be found. It does come from my frustration as an engineer myself from seeing relatively distinct technical issues become political and messy. I could be wrong and the solution is just better information, education, and understanding by all so that it can be dealt with more democratically - but that doesn't seem to help much in this particular situation.
tonys 04/20/2022 3:40 AM
So lets take a review to how the Lora Alliance has created the different Band Plans in the Regional Parameters specification In no particular date order. - We start out with US Regulator allowing LoraWan to operate in the 902-918 MHz band. Quite a nice wide band that allows the Alliance to allocate 64 uplink channels and 8 downlink channels all on different frequencies - Then comes Europe and they have around 8 channels but in the 868MHz area. So the Alliance establishes a second plan. - Along comes the Australian regulator and has less spectrum available than the US so the Alliance creates another bandplan, sort of like the the US plan, still has 64 uplink channels but being a bit more condensed the downlink channels overlap to top end of the band. - The comes Japan and they have even less channels available and these are in the top end only of the US plan. So the Alliance creates yet another plan. - Korea does something different and the Alliance create another plan.
2
03:40
You can see where this is heading. The Alliance is flat out (like a lizard drinking) creating new plans everytime a country has the slightest change from something already available in another country. So the Alliance takes a different approach and starts to create Band Plans controlled by Parameters and by way of example this creates the AS923-1, AS923-2 etc etc where its the same concept only set by an Offset Frequency. This means a node manufacturer can ship to a country who have a few channels down the bottom end of the 900MHz spectrum and the same firmware will be suitable for another country who has a few channels up at the top end of the 900MHz spectrum. The channels are not common in these countries but for a device manufacturer a simple Parameter in a configuration file will make the firmware suitable in both countries. Now, to date all the focus of LoraWan has been on ISM bands but I can see the day when LoraWan will be used on frequencies outside the ISM bands, on channels licenced and paid for by the operator. So instead of creating yet another band plan, i can foresee the Alliance going further and developing a parameterised plan even far more flexible than seen to date. As you can see all of this is associated with eliminating workload and complexity on the LoraAlliance and also on the device manufacturers.
03:41
Now lets go back and review the existing bandplans. Take for example the US915 system. It works, its fine, it provides access to the full spectrum offered by the regulator and there is no need to change. EU868 also works and again there is no need to change. However given what we know now (key word here is Hindsight) it may have been done differently if we started over. A good example of this will be the EU915 system won't be configured like EU868 or US915 but will probably be based on a more universal solution of configuration parameters. So the take away message. AU915 is like US915, it provides access to the complete spectrum allocated by the Australian Regulator. Like US915 as it utilised in the US, AU915 works and is a suitable solution in Australia. While there may be more flexible allocation systems in the pipeline, the existing AU915 system works just fine and works jast as adequately as the US915 system does, there is no need to change. All the bells and whistles in AS923 or any other firmware doesn't provide any more features than already available. The term Dynamic Plans really are about providing a flexible system to avoid the need to create yet another Band Plan and yet another version of firmware.
2
vudu 04/20/2022 3:55 AM
STFU. @tonys nails it again. Lol. Look up at he pages of blah blah blah. Progress? Yeah, none. Self serving narrative proffered as a solution. Yeah, Nah again from me. In the professional engineering circles where I come from. The software engineers run their "thing" on the hardware we build, test, maintain and support. We are those whose phone rings in the morning. We adhere to ITIL and change control. We have a backout plan. We discourage and actively block the cowboys whose lack of consideration reflects their accountability and the efforts of those affected. I stand by those that resist change to the status quo for lack of due diligence. In other words. Formal dissent.

And the helium documents says Morocco frequency is EU433 . Many devices there and more people they want to involve in helium but the problem still not fixed.
mvierling 06/26/2022 3:49 PM
Morocco regulations appear to allow both EU433 and EU868. However EU433 is rarely used and the Morocco regulations only allow 10mW maximum power for the EU433 band. Seems reasonable to update to EU868. (edited)

SiMoWeb3NfT
I think there‚Äôs no helium device manufacturers produce EU433. But seriously I don‚Äôt understand why they give Morocco EU433 its very wired seriously. And all devices there are EU868 . What you think they can change the frequency in the future or it‚Äôs impossible.
mvierling 06/27/2022 12:49 PM
Until very recently, the LoRa Alliance Regional spec only listed EU433 for Morocco. This is likely the only reason Helium choose EU433. The Regional Spec now lists both EU433 and EU868. In general LoRa network operators always prefer EU868 over EU433 for many reasons. Helium engineering will work to have Morocco changed to EU868 (edited)
gradoj 06/27/2022 6:09 PM
Morocco only supports 868.0-869.0 so can use the mandatory channels 0,1,2 but that is it. Doesn't helium send a channel mask after joining with other channels in the 867MHz? Would you still call it EU868? How do the sensors there know not to use 867Mhz channels?

gazmcghee
I don't know what you mean. On the gateway side, Helium controls that so no user setting required. On the device side the user would only need to select AS923 or AU915 and be fully compliant to that standard. In my case, the devices are not - they are fixed to a set of 8 AU915 channels. (edited)

waveform 08/15/2022 12:36 PM
A repeat of the statement on HIP45 before the channel is locked: from #foundation-announcements HIP-45 was authored to confront ambiguity in regional frequency plan selection. While there has been spirited discussion within the community on regional selections, this potentially creates further fragmentation of the LoRaWAN standard and is a flawed approach. A LoRaWAN sensor should consistently work on LoRaWAN networks around the world, whether Helium or otherwise. If frictionless onboarding and network utility are our guiding principles, it becomes an imperative that LoRaWAN maintains consistency across network providers. For this reason, we believe HIP-45 is the wrong approach and regional selections should be addressed at LoRa Alliance level rather than siloed within the Helium Network. As of today, we‚Äôre moving the responsibility of regional frequency selection to the LoRa Alliance and marking HIP-45 as invalidated due to (a) fragmentation of the LoRaWAN standard (b) ambiguity around the approval process at the time. The LoRa Alliance is the governing body of the LoRaWAN standard and is responsible for regulating global frequency plans as well as other LoRaWAN issues (NetIDs, LoRaWAN protocol, architecture etc.) As the largest LoRaWAN deployment, the Helium Network plays a significant role in helping to set LoRa Alliance standards to create a more unified global network. Rather than making siloed decisions through our own committees, this conversation is most effective within the LoRa Alliance framework, specifically the LoRa Alliance Regional Parameters Working Group, which makes regional frequency decisions. The Helium Foundation is a contributing member of the LoRa Alliance. For more information on the LoRa Alliance including the process to become a member of a LoRa Alliance committee, please visit https://lora-alliance.org/ As stated this HIP has been invalidated and the Channel is now locked before being archived. Updates about LoRaWAN frequency allocations will be in #foundation-announcements
Homepage - LoRa Alliance®
Exported 1,572 message(s)
